Location of Incident: Meeth-Aker village in Gogrial East
Description: 6.	On 17 January, three secondary sources reported that, on the same day, armed Nuer Youths from Mayom County in Unity State, shot and killed two Dinka Apuk male civilians and injured five others in Meeth-Aker village in Gogrial East County. According to the sources the attackers invaded Meeth-Aker village to raid cattle and in the process shot sporadically on the civilians tending to their cattle and raided an unspecified herd of cattle and fled the scene towards Mayom County.

Location of Incident: Meeth-Aker village in Gogrial East
Description: 6.	On 17 January, three secondary sources reported that, on the same day, armed Nuer Youths from Mayom County in Unity State, shot and killed two Dinka Apuk male civilians and injured five others in Meeth-Aker village in Gogrial East County. According to the sources the attackers invaded Meeth-Aker village to raid cattle and in the process shot sporadically on the civilians tending to their cattle and raided an unspecified herd of cattle and fled the scene towards Mayom County.

Location of Incident: Meeth-Aker village in Gogrial East
Description: 6.	On 17 January, three secondary sources reported that, on the same day, armed Nuer Youths from Mayom County in Unity State, shot and killed two Dinka Apuk male civilians and injured five others in Meeth-Aker village in Gogrial East County. According to the sources the attackers invaded Meeth-Aker village to raid cattle and in the process shot sporadically on the civilians tending to their cattle and raided an unspecified herd of cattle and fled the scene towards Mayom County.

Location of Incident: Cuei-Chok village, Manyangok Payam, Tonj South
Description:
7.	On 18 January, three secondary sources reported that, on 17 January, armed Dinka Gok youths from Cueibet County- Lakes State, shot and killed five Dinka Thony civilians (three males and two females) and injured two others (male and female) in Cuei-Chok village, Manyangok Payam, Tonj South County. According to the sources, the incident happened when the assailants indiscriminately opened fire on Dinka Thony civilians while they attended a wedding ceremony. Reportedly, this incident is part of the longstanding history of violence between the Dinka Thony in Tonj South County and the Dinka Gok in Cueibet County. The injured victims were evacuated to a health facility in Tonj South County for further medical treatment. 

Comment: HRD will continue to follow up on these incidents with the respective County authorities for more information.

Location of Incident: Cuei-Chok village, Manyangok Payam, Tonj South
Description:
7.	On 18 January, three secondary sources reported that, on 17 January, armed Dinka Gok youths from Cueibet County- Lakes State, shot and killed five Dinka Thony civilians (three males and two females) and injured two others (male and female) in Cuei-Chok village, Manyangok Payam, Tonj South County. According to the sources, the incident happened when the assailants indiscriminately opened fire on Dinka Thony civilians while they attended a wedding ceremony. Reportedly, this incident is part of the longstanding history of violence between the Dinka Thony in Tonj South County and the Dinka Gok in Cueibet County. The injured victims were evacuated to a health facility in Tonj South County for further medical treatment. 

Comment: HRD will continue to follow up on these incidents with the respective County authorities for more information.

Location of Incident: New Side Residential area in Wau municipality, Wau town, Wau
Description:
8.	On 17 January, multiple sources reported that on 29 September 2024, one 30-year-old male SSNPS officer, raped one 13-year-old girl (with epilepsy) in New Side Residential area in Wau municipality, Wau town, Wau County. According to the sources, the suspect entered the survivor’s homestead at night where she was sleeping with her younger brother and raped her, fled the scene leaving her bleeding. Reportedly, the survivor’s younger brother alerted other relatives who rushed to the scene, identified the suspect as he was escaping, and took the victim to a health facility in Wau town for treatment. The incident was reported to the police, who arrested and detained the suspect at the Wau Central Prison.

Comment: Although the suspect has been released on bail, judicial proceedings commenced, and two sessions have been done on 11 October and 27 December respectively, and the case has been adjourned to 22 January for a third hearing. HRD will continue to follow the proceedings for a final verdict on the case.

Location of Incident: Wau town, Wau
Description:
9.	Between 17 and 19 January, multiple sources reported that four civilians were killed (three Sudanese including one refugee and one 20-year-old male South Sudanese) and 25 others were injured (20 male Sudanese nationals and five South Sudanese including three boys, one girl, one and one 26-year-old medical doctor) during violent protests targeting Sudanese nationals in Wau town, Wau County and Boro Madina, Raja County respectively. According to the source, of the injured victims, a total of 12 was registered in Wau County, and eight received medical treatment at different health facilities in Wau County and of the 13 injured Raja County, the two injured and in critical conditions were transferred to a health facility in Raja town for treatment. Reportedly, the retaliatory violence was sparked following the news of the alleged killing of South Sudanese nationals in Al Jazirah state in Southeast Khartoum in Sudan, allegedly by the Sudan Armed Forces.

Comment: HRD will continue to gather more information on these events in Western Bahr el Ghazal State and as the situation gradually returns to normal.

Update: 3.	On 20 January, one secondary source reported that, on the same day, of the two Sudanese nationals who were injured and in critical condition and admitted at a health facility in Boro Madina in Raja County following the targeted retaliatory attacks against Sudanese nationals [see HRD Daily Report 20 January 2025], one has succumbed to his injuries. 

Comment: This brings the total deaths in Western Bahr el Ghazal State to five civilians (previously reported four) and the number of injured victims reduced to 24 (previously reported 25). HRD will continue to follow-up for more updates on the incidents.

Location of Incident: Wau town, Wau
Description:
9.	Between 17 and 19 January, multiple sources reported that four civilians were killed (three Sudanese including one refugee and one 20-year-old male South Sudanese) and 25 others were injured (20 male Sudanese nationals and five South Sudanese including three boys, one girl, one and one 26-year-old medical doctor) during violent protests targeting Sudanese nationals in Wau town, Wau County and Boro Madina, Raja County respectively. According to the source, of the injured victims, a total of 12 was registered in Wau County, and eight received medical treatment at different health facilities in Wau County and of the 13 injured Raja County, the two injured and in critical conditions were transferred to a health facility in Raja town for treatment. Reportedly, the retaliatory violence was sparked following the news of the alleged killing of South Sudanese nationals in Al Jazirah state in Southeast Khartoum in Sudan, allegedly by the Sudan Armed Forces.

Comment: HRD will continue to gather more information on these events in Western Bahr el Ghazal State and as the situation gradually returns to normal.

Update: 3.	On 20 January, one secondary source reported that, on the same day, of the two Sudanese nationals who were injured and in critical condition and admitted at a health facility in Boro Madina in Raja County following the targeted retaliatory attacks against Sudanese nationals [see HRD Daily Report 20 January 2025], one has succumbed to his injuries. 

Comment: This brings the total deaths in Western Bahr el Ghazal State to five civilians (previously reported four) and the number of injured victims reduced to 24 (previously reported 25). HRD will continue to follow-up for more updates on the incidents.

Location of Incident: markets of Konyo-konyo and Hai Thoura in the new site and Mia Saba residential areas
Description:
UNMISS HRD FLASH REPORT – 18 January 2025:
Attacks on Civilians by Unidentified Armed Protestors in Juba, Aweil, Malakal and Wau
Summary:
1.	Between 15-18 January 2025, UNMISS HRD documented attacks on civilians, looting, and the destruction of civilian property by unidentified armed protestors in several areas of South Sudan, including hotspots areas in Juba City, Central Equatoria State; Malakal town, Upper Nile State, Wau and Boro Madina towns in Western Bahr el Ghazal State; and Aweil town, Northern Bahr el Ghazal State. Further, tensions are reportedly high in Abiemnom County, Ruweng Administrative Area and Mayom County, Unity State. These incidents, allegedly targeting Sudanese traders and refugees in South Sudan, were reportedly triggered by the alleged killing of South Sudanese nationals during the recapture of Wad Madeni town in Al-Jazirah State (Southeast of Khartoum) from RSF by Sudan Armed Forces (SAF). 

2.	As of 21 January, UNMISS HRD documented a total of 270 civilian casualties (30 killed and 240 injured), including 22 women and 55 children (53 boys and two girls), linked to the attacks. Fifteen out of 270 were (confirmed) South Sudanese. Reportedly, 20 civilians (Sudanese traders) were allegedly killed and 35 others injured by unidentified armed protestors in Aweil town; another five civilians were injured in Malakal town; six killed and 175 others injured in Juba town; and four killed and 25 others injured in Wau town, Wau County and Boro Madina, Raja County in Western Bhar El Ghazal. Additionally, incidents of looting, and the destruction of civilian properties in Juba, Aweil West and Aweil East Counties, and within the POC site in Malakal were also recorded. Further, unverified reports alleged that members of the government security forces used live rounds of ammunitions to disperse the protestors in Juba City and Aweil town. 

3.	In Aweil and Wau, secondary displacement was experienced by an estimated 4,075 Sudanese nationals (2,451 in Aweil and 1,624 in Wau) who have sought protection and refuge at various Government offices and facilities (i.e. NSS, SSPDF, SSNPS, etc.)

4.	These incidents pose a significant threat to human rights and the protection of civilians. Notably, attacks on Sudanese civilians by unidentified armed protestors may constitute grave abuses of the right to life and security of the person. In addition, UNMISS HRD has received preliminary information regarding content being circulated on social media platforms which may amount to misinformation, disinformation, or hate speech. Further, the unverified reports of the use of live rounds of ammunitions by the members of the government security forces to disperse protestors may constitute excessive use of force and may infringe upon the right to freedom of peaceful assembly in certain cases (further is investigation required). Nevertheless, based on the preliminary information received, the government security forces have implemented positive measures to protect Sudanese civilians from the threats posed by the unidentified armed protestors in compliance with their obligation to protect the right to life. 

5.	Recommended responses by UNMISS HRD include: 
i.	advocacy and engagement with government officials and security forces in hotspot locations to promote compliance with international human rights law standards on the use of force, and freedom of assembly.
ii.	advocacy and engagement with State authorities and community leaders in hotspot locations to reduce tensions and promote peace; and
iii.	enhanced monitoring and reporting of the human rights situation in hotspot locations (including monitoring of misinformation, disinformation, and hate speech), and follow-up on unconfirmed, preliminary information. 

Documented Human Rights Violations/Abuses (Preliminary Information):
6.	In Juba, six civilians were reportedly killed and 175 others injured, including 22 women and 47 children (all boys). On 17 January, armed protesters looted shops owned by Sudanese nationals in markets of Konyo-konyo and Hai Thoura in the new site and Mia Saba residential areas. These acts are an extension of the protest which started on 16 January in Juba, in front of the Sudanese Embassy against the killing of South Sudanese in Sudan. 

7.	In Malakal, on 15 January, special forces of the SSPDF injured one civilian during an attack on two humanitarian boats owned by Doctors without Borders (MSF) transporting patients from Ulang County to Nassir County. The motive for the attack is yet unknown. Separately, on 16 January, an unspecified number of Sudanese nationals were attacked and robbed by unidentified youths in the PoC site. Reportedly, the Sudanese traders rushed to the PoC site for safety after their shops were demolished in Malakal town on the evening of the same day as part of the protest for the killing of South Sudanese in Sudan. Between 16-17 January, a total of five civilians were injured and received treatment at MSF health facility in connection to the ongoing violence. Between 18 and 19 January, there were reports of from multiple secondary sources of random attacks against civilians by members of youth gangs armed with matchets around the Malakal PoC site. This new development reportedly was not connected to the targeting of Sudanese national, thereby falling within the criminal jurisdiction of local law enforcement.  
8.	In Aweil, on 17 January, unidentified armed protesters killed 20 civilians (17 Sudanese and three South Sudanese, including one child) and 35 others severely injured, including five South Sudanese, three of whom were children (two boys and 1 girl), during a violent protest in Aweil town, Aweil County. 
9.	In Wau, between 17 and 19 January, multiple sources reported that four civilians were killed (three Sudanese and one South Sudanese) and 25 others were injured (20 Sudanese and five South Sudanese, including four children [three boys and one girl]) during violent protests targeting Sudanese nationals in Wau town, Wau County and Boro Madina, Raja County respectively.

Description:
UNMISS HRD FLASH REPORT – 18 January 2025:
Attacks on Civilians by Unidentified Armed Protestors in Juba, Aweil, Malakal and Wau
Summary:
1.	Between 15-18 January 2025, UNMISS HRD documented attacks on civilians, looting, and the destruction of civilian property by unidentified armed protestors in several areas of South Sudan, including hotspots areas in Juba City, Central Equatoria State; Malakal town, Upper Nile State, Wau and Boro Madina towns in Western Bahr el Ghazal State; and Aweil town, Northern Bahr el Ghazal State. Further, tensions are reportedly high in Abiemnom County, Ruweng Administrative Area and Mayom County, Unity State. These incidents, allegedly targeting Sudanese traders and refugees in South Sudan, were reportedly triggered by the alleged killing of South Sudanese nationals during the recapture of Wad Madeni town in Al-Jazirah State (Southeast of Khartoum) from RSF by Sudan Armed Forces (SAF). 

2.	As of 21 January, UNMISS HRD documented a total of 270 civilian casualties (30 killed and 240 injured), including 22 women and 55 children (53 boys and two girls), linked to the attacks. Fifteen out of 270 were (confirmed) South Sudanese. Reportedly, 20 civilians (Sudanese traders) were allegedly killed and 35 others injured by unidentified armed protestors in Aweil town; another five civilians were injured in Malakal town; six killed and 175 others injured in Juba town; and four killed and 25 others injured in Wau town, Wau County and Boro Madina, Raja County in Western Bhar El Ghazal. Additionally, incidents of looting, and the destruction of civilian properties in Juba, Aweil West and Aweil East Counties, and within the POC site in Malakal were also recorded. Further, unverified reports alleged that members of the government security forces used live rounds of ammunitions to disperse the protestors in Juba City and Aweil town. 

3.	In Aweil and Wau, secondary displacement was experienced by an estimated 4,075 Sudanese nationals (2,451 in Aweil and 1,624 in Wau) who have sought protection and refuge at various Government offices and facilities (i.e. NSS, SSPDF, SSNPS, etc.)

4.	These incidents pose a significant threat to human rights and the protection of civilians. Notably, attacks on Sudanese civilians by unidentified armed protestors may constitute grave abuses of the right to life and security of the person. In addition, UNMISS HRD has received preliminary information regarding content being circulated on social media platforms which may amount to misinformation, disinformation, or hate speech. Further, the unverified reports of the use of live rounds of ammunitions by the members of the government security forces to disperse protestors may constitute excessive use of force and may infringe upon the right to freedom of peaceful assembly in certain cases (further is investigation required). Nevertheless, based on the preliminary information received, the government security forces have implemented positive measures to protect Sudanese civilians from the threats posed by the unidentified armed protestors in compliance with their obligation to protect the right to life. 

5.	Recommended responses by UNMISS HRD include: 
i.	advocacy and engagement with government officials and security forces in hotspot locations to promote compliance with international human rights law standards on the use of force, and freedom of assembly.
ii.	advocacy and engagement with State authorities and community leaders in hotspot locations to reduce tensions and promote peace; and
iii.	enhanced monitoring and reporting of the human rights situation in hotspot locations (including monitoring of misinformation, disinformation, and hate speech), and follow-up on unconfirmed, preliminary information. 

Documented Human Rights Violations/Abuses (Preliminary Information):
6.	In Juba, six civilians were reportedly killed and 175 others injured, including 22 women and 47 children (all boys). On 17 January, armed protesters looted shops owned by Sudanese nationals in markets of Konyo-konyo and Hai Thoura in the new site and Mia Saba residential areas. These acts are an extension of the protest which started on 16 January in Juba, in front of the Sudanese Embassy against the killing of South Sudanese in Sudan. 

7.	In Malakal, on 15 January, special forces of the SSPDF injured one civilian during an attack on two humanitarian boats owned by Doctors without Borders (MSF) transporting patients from Ulang County to Nassir County. The motive for the attack is yet unknown. Separately, on 16 January, an unspecified number of Sudanese nationals were attacked and robbed by unidentified youths in the PoC site. Reportedly, the Sudanese traders rushed to the PoC site for safety after their shops were demolished in Malakal town on the evening of the same day as part of the protest for the killing of South Sudanese in Sudan. Between 16-17 January, a total of five civilians were injured and received treatment at MSF health facility in connection to the ongoing violence. Between 18 and 19 January, there were reports of from multiple secondary sources of random attacks against civilians by members of youth gangs armed with matchets around the Malakal PoC site. This new development reportedly was not connected to the targeting of Sudanese national, thereby falling within the criminal jurisdiction of local law enforcement.  
8.	In Aweil, on 17 January, unidentified armed protesters killed 20 civilians (17 Sudanese and three South Sudanese, including one child) and 35 others severely injured, including five South Sudanese, three of whom were children (two boys and 1 girl), during a violent protest in Aweil town, Aweil County. 
9.	In Wau, between 17 and 19 January, multiple sources reported that four civilians were killed (three Sudanese and one South Sudanese) and 25 others were injured (20 Sudanese and five South Sudanese, including four children [three boys and one girl]) during violent protests targeting Sudanese nationals in Wau town, Wau County and Boro Madina, Raja County respectively.

Location of Incident: Poktap, Duk County, Jonglei State
Description:
1.	On the evening of 16 January 2025, tensions erupted in Juba as groups of unidentified armed South Sudanese protestors took-over some areas in Juba to protest the killing of South Sudanese civilians during the recapture of Wad Madani in Al-Jazirah State,  Sudan, from the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) by the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF).  Though the unrest was initially contained by the South Sudan Government security forces, the violence escalated when groups of violent South Sudanese men mobilized to target the Sudanese communities and other nationalities, including business owners in various parts of Juba, Central Equatoria State and Aweil, Northern Bahr El Ghazal State. Further, similar patterns of civil unrest occurred in Bor town and Duk County, Jonglei State; Malakal and Renk town, Upper Nile State; Wau and Boro Madina towns in Western Bahr El Ghazal State; and Kuajok Town, Gogrial West County and Tonj, Tonj South County in Warrap State. Linked to the escalation of civil unrest in parts of these areas, UNMISS HRD documented attacks on civilians, looting, and the destruction of civilian properties by unidentified South Sudanese armed elements, as well as displacement of civilians, mainly of Sudanese origin. Similarly, tensions were reportedly high in Abiemnom County, Ruweng Administrative Area and Mayom County, Unity State against the Sudanese community in the area. 

2.	As of 24 January, UNMISS HRD documented a total of 304 civilian casualties (39 killed and 265 injured), including 22 women and 55 children (53 boys and two girls), linked to the civil unrest.  Fifteen out of 304 civilian casualties were (confirmed) South Sudanese. Reportedly, 20 civilians (Sudanese traders) were allegedly killed and 35 others injured by unidentified armed protestors in Aweil town, Wanyjok, and Nyamlel, Northern Bharr el Ghazal State; six killed and 175 others injured in Juba, Central Equatoria State;  five killed and 31 others injured in Wau town, Wau County and Boro Madina, Raja County in Western Bhar El Ghazal State; one killed and seven injured in Renk and Malakal town, Upper Nile State; one killed in Maridi County, Western Equatoria State; one killed in Duk County, Jonglei State; and five civilians (including three South Sudanese) were killed and 17 others injured in Twic and  Tonj South Counties, Warrap State.  


10.	Jonglei State. In Poktap, Duk County, Jonglei State, one civilian was killed by random gunshots after local youth tried to overrun the market, and the security forces began shooting in the air to disperse the crowd

Location of Incident: Maridi County, Western Equatoria State

16.	In Western Equatoria State, a Sudanese businessman (who was also an Imam) from Yambio County, was reportedly shot and killed by an unidentified gunman in Maridi County on 21 January, following the spread of information that a group of Sudanese were celebrating the incident in Wad Madani that claimed the lives of South Sudanese individuals.

Location of Incident: Kauto Boma, Kauto Payam, Kapoeta East
Description:
1.	On 20 January, three secondary sources reported that, on 17 January, armed Suruma men from Ethiopia, shot and killed one 25-year-old male civilian from the Toposa community in Kauto Boma, Kauto Payam, Kapoeta East County. According to the sources, the assailants crossed from Ethiopia and attacked a cattle camp in Kauto Boma, to raid cattle belonging to the Toposa, where they shot and killed the victim while he was tending to his cattle. Reportedly, they attempted to raid the victim’s cattle but were fended off by armed Toposa youts who mobilized and pursued them over the border back to Ethiopia. The incident was reported to the Kapoeta East County police and investigation are ongoing. 

Comment: HRD will continue to follow-up on this incident for more information.

Location of Incident: Panyijar town, Panyijar
Description:
2.	On 20 January, one primary source and two secondary sources reported that on 17 January, armed Nyong Nuer youths shot and killed two boys (aged 8 and 15 years) and injured six other adult male civilians in Panyijar town, Panyijar County. According to the sources, the incident happened during a squabble between two Nyong Nuer armed groups (one from Mar village and the other from Pamalual village) over the rightful ownership of an AK47 riffle and in the process, one of the groups accidentally discharged the riffle killing and injuring the victims. Reportedly, one victim died on the spot, while the other succumbed to his injuries while he was taken alongside the other injured victims to a health facility in the area for treatment. The government, traditional and security officials are working to resolve the situation and prevent any escalation no arrests had been made in connection to the incident.

Comment: HRD will continue to follow-up on this report for more information and push for corrective action to hold the perpetrators accountable in line with the extant criminal law in force.

Location of Incident: Tambura town, Tambura
Description:
4.	On 20 January, two secondary sources reported that, on 18 January, the SSPDF arbitrarily arrested and detained two male civilians from the Balanda community, in Tambura town, Tambura County.  According to the sources, the victims were traveling from Nagero to Tambura town, when the SSPDF arrested and detained them upon their arrival to Tambura town for unknown reasons. 

Comment: HRD will engage the leadership of the SSPDF in Tambura town, to ascertain the motive for their arrest and detention, and advocate for their transfer to the local police custody with the requisite criminal jurisdiction, where they can be investigated based on the charges against them.

Location of Incident: Chahari Boma, Chahari Payam, Ikotos
Description: 2.	On 21 January, three secondary sources reported that on 17 January, one 23-year-old male civilian was shot and killed and a 21-year-old male civilian was injured, both from the Logir community, during retaliatory violence in Chahari Boma, Chahari Payam, Ikotos County. According to the sources, armed Logir youths from Hiriafit Boma opened fire on a group of Logir youths from Chahari Boma following a dispute that erupted during a traditional dance, injuring the 21-year-old victim. In retaliation, armed Logir youths from Chahari Boma shot and killed the 23-year-old victim from Hiriafit Boma during a pursuit of , armed Logir youths from Hiriafit Boma. The injured victim was evacuated to a health care facility in Chahari Boma for medical treatment.

Location of Incident: Luak Kel village, Dualjany Boma, Tut Payam, Nyirol
Description: 3.	On 21 January, multiple sources reported that on 20 January, Murle armed elements shot and injured one 47-year-old male civilian from the Lou Nuer community in Luak Kel village, Dualjany Boma, Tut Payam, Nyirol County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements opened fire on the victim while being pursued by Lou Nuer youths for raiding an unspecified number of cattle from a cattle camp in Luak Kel village. The victim was evacuated to a health care facility in Nyirol County for medical treatment.

Location of Incident: Luak Kel village, Dualjany Boma, Tut Payam, Nyirol

Location of Incident: Walgak, Akobo
Description: 4.	On 21 January, multiple sources reported that on 20 December 2024, Murle armed elements shot and killed one male civilian from the Lou Nuer community in Walgak Payam, Akobo County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements ambushed and opened fire on a group of Lou Nuer youths, injuring the victim who subsequently succumbed to the injuries at a at a health care facility. Reportedly, the  incident follows the raiding of eight heads of cattle from Diro Payam on 19 December 2024.

Location of Incident: Walgak, Akobo

Location of Incident: Gumuruk, GPAA
Description: 5.	Between 20 and 21 January, multiple sources reported that on 19 January, one six-year-old boy from the Murle community who had been abducted alongside 11 other civilians during the attacks by armed youths from Jonglei State on 13 December 2024 in Gumuruk County, Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) [see HRD Daily Report 30 December 2024] was recovered by the authorities in Bor Town, Bor County.  According to the Sources, on 17 January, the boy was released by a group of armed Lou Nuer youths to a group of locals in Makuach, Kolnyang Payam, Bor South County who subsequently informed the authorities. Reportedly, the authorities have commenced family tracing and reunification process.

Location of Incident: Danga village, Ngabagok Payam, Tonj East
Description:
7.	On 21 January, three secondary sources reported that on 20 January, armed Dinka Thiik youths shot and killed two male civilians from the Dinka Akook community and injured two others during an attempted cattle raid in Danga village, Ngabagok Payam, Tonj East County. The  injured victims were reportedly evacuated to a health care facility in Ngabagok Payam for medical treatment.

Comment: According to the sources, tension is mounting in the area, with the likelihood of retaliatory violence by Dinka Akook youths in the absence of proactive measure by the authorities to defuse the situation.

Location of Incident: Makpandu Boma, Bangasu Payam, Yambio
Description: 8.	On 21 January, multiple sources reported that on 17 January, SSNPS personnel shot and killed one male civilian and injured another in Makpandu Boma, Bangasu Payam, Yambio County. According to the sources, SSNPS personnel opened fire on victims as they  escaped from police custody, after being detained on allegations of theft of an unspecified sum of South Sudanese Pounds (SSP) and United States Dollars from an Eritrean businessman in Yambio Town. The injured victim was evacuated to a health care facility in Makpandu Boma for medical treatment. The SSNPS personnel who opened fire on the victims remain at large.

Location of Incident: Makpandu Boma, Bangasu Payam, Yambio
Description: 8.	On 21 January, multiple sources reported that on 17 January, SSNPS personnel shot and killed one male civilian and injured another in Makpandu Boma, Bangasu Payam, Yambio County. According to the sources, SSNPS personnel opened fire on victims as they  escaped from police custody, after being detained on allegations of theft of an unspecified sum of South Sudanese Pounds (SSP) and United States Dollars from an Eritrean businessman in Yambio Town. The injured victim was evacuated to a health care facility in Makpandu Boma for medical treatment. The SSNPS personnel who opened fire on the victims remain at large.

Location of Incident: Mogiri, Juba
Description:
1.	On 22 January, two secondary sources reported that on 19 and 21 January, suspected Murle armed elements shot and killed three male civilians (ages 24, 25, and 42 years old) in Mogiri Boma, Juba County. According to the sources, on 19 January, suspected Murle armed elements ambushed and opened fire on two civilians (the 24- and 25-year-old men) while they were travelling along the Mogiri-Bilinyang road, killing them. On 21 January, the body of the 42-year-old male resident of Mogiri Boma, who had been missing for two days, was found near a newly established health care facility in Mogiri, suspected to have been killed by Murle armed elements allegedly roaming in Mogiri Boma.

Comment: Although victims have reported the incidents to local authorities, there have been no arrests or significant progress in investigations. The lack of timely law enforcement response and accountability measures raises serious concerns regarding the protection of civilians, impunity, and the rule of law. The ongoing insecurity has instilled fear among the local population, limiting their freedom of movement and access to livelihoods.

Location of Incident: Lokorojo Boma, Kauto Payam, Kapoeta East
Description:
2.	On 22 January, three secondary sources reported that on 17 January, armed Toposa youths shot and killed three male civilians from the Murle community in Lokorojo Boma, Kauto Payam, Kapoeta East County. According to the sources, a group of armed Toposa youths who were patrolling in Kauto Payam encountered the victims in the outskirts of Lokorojo Boma and opened fire, killing them – on suspicion of spying on cattle camps and grazing areas.  

Comment: According to the sources, there is heavy mobilization by armed Toposa youths in Kauto Payam following allegations of movement of a large group of Murle armed elements from Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) towards Kapoeta East County for cattle raids. Consequently, Toposa women and children have reportedly vacated  their villages in Kauto Payam and sought refuge in the villages of Kuron, Namurpus, Moruse, Lomare , Nabokagacna, Nakubusa, Nakadego, Napotogiria, Namenoyi, Kagerba, and Nachodokopele.

Location of Incident: Padiet Payam, Duk
Description: 3.	On 22 January, multiple sources reported that on 20 January, Murle armed elements shot and killed one 27-year-old female civilian and injured one 41-year-old male civilian, both from the Dinka community, in Padiet Payam, Duk County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements attacked and opened fire on a group of Dinka civilians who were travelling from Pagak Payam to Padiet Payam, killing one and injuring another. Reportedly, the injured victim was evacuated to a health care facility in Duk Padiet for medical treatment.

Location of Incident: Padiet Payam, Duk
Description: 3. Location of Incident: Pajut Boma, Panyang Payam, Duk
Description: 4.	On 22 January, multiple sources reported that on 20 January, Murle armed elements abducted two children (one eight-year-old boy and a 16-year-old girl) from the Lou Nuer community in Pajut Boma, Panyang Payam, Duk County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements attacked a group of Lou Nuer civilians who were traveling from Pajut to Patuet in Panyang Payam and abducted the two children. The whereabouts of the abductees remains unknown.

Location of Incident: Thol
Description:
5.	On 22 January, multiple sources reported that on 21 January, one 19-year-old woman from the Lou Nuer community who had been abducted long with 19 other Lou Nuer women and children from Thol Payam, Nyirol County by Murle armed elements on 13 December 2024 [see HRD Daily Report 17 December 2024] was recovered by the authorities in Gadiang Payam, Duk County. According to the sources, the victim escaped from her abductors in Majak Boma, Gumuruk County (GPAA). Reportedly, the authorities are coordinating with protection partners to provide treatment and facilitate family tracing and reunification.

Comment: HRD will continue to follow-up with the authorities for more information on the family reunification process.

Location of Incident: Kaatnaar, Alieny County, Ruweng Administrative Area
Description: 6.	On 22 January, multiple sources reported that on 21 January, unidentified armed elements shot and injured two male civilians (one 20-year-old Dinka Panaruu and a 23-year-old Leek Nuer), contractors working for an oil company, in Kaatnaar, Alieny County, Ruweng Administrative Area. According to the sources, the assailants attacked and opened fire on security personnel who were providing security at an oil field where the victims working, injuring them. Reportedly, the victims were evacuated to health care facilities in Pariang and Bentiu for medical treatment. The sources further informed that the authorities deployed the NSS and South Sudan People’s Defence Forces (SSPDF) to the area to avert further violence.

Location of Incident: Apuor Lok village, Awul Payam, Tonj North
Description: 7.	On 22 January, three secondary sources reported that on 21 January, armed Dinka Atok youths shot and killed one male civilian from the Dinka Jurlian community and injured two others during a cattle raid in Apuor Lok village, Awul Payam, Tonj North County. the attackers also seized an unspecified heads of cattle. The victims were reportedly killed and injured during a confrontation between the attackers and local Dinka Jurlian youths, as they  attempted to recover the stolen cattle. The injured victims were evacuated to a health a facility in Rualbet Payam for medical treatment.

Location of Incident: Apuor Lok village, Awul Payam, Tonj North
Description: 7.	On 22 January, three secondary sources reported that on 21 January, armed Dinka Atok youths shot and killed one male civilian from the Dinka Jurlian community and injured two others during a cattle raid in Apuor Lok village, Awul Payam, Tonj North County. the attackers also seized an unspecified heads of cattle. The victims were reportedly killed and injured during a confrontation between the attackers and local Dinka Jurlian youths, as they  attempted to recover the stolen cattle. Location of Incident: Wau town, Wau
Description:
8.	On 22 January, one primary source reported that on 17 January, one NSS personnel shot and injured a 40-year-old male civilian from the Nuer community in Wau Town, Wau County. As recounted the source, the NSS personnel opened fire on the victim while he was walking towards his shop in Wau Town, injuring him, and thereafter fled the scene. The victim was evacuated to a health care facility in Wau Town for medical treatment.

Comment: HRD will follow up on the incident for accountability of the perpetrator.

Location of Incident: Mapoko Adio, Tore Payam, Yei River
Description:
1.	On 23 January, two secondary sources reported that on 16 January, suspected armed Ambororo cattle keepers shot and killed one male civilian from Avukaya community in Mapoko Adio, Tore Payam, Yei River County. According to the sources, the assailants opened fire on the victim while he was fishing at the Yei River, killing him. The motive for the killing remains unknown.

Comments: The incident raises concerns about security and protection of civilians in areas occupied by armed cattle keepers. HRD will follow up on the incident with the authorities and urge for investigation and accountability of the perpetrators.

Location of Incident: in Lafon County, Imehejek Administrative Area
Description: 2.	On 23 January, three secondary sources reported that on 5 and 10 January, two victims of abduction (one 14-year-old girl and a four-year-old boy) from the Lopit community in Lafon County, Imehejek Administrative Area were recovered by the authorities in Maruwa Payam, Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA). According to the sources, the children were abducted by the Murle armed elements along Mogiri-Juba Road in April and July 2023 (exact date unspecified) when they were 12 and two-years old, respectively. Reportedly, the family of the 14-year-old girl has been identified; however, the children are still awaiting transfer to Juba to be reunited with their families in Eastern Equatoria.

Location of Incident: Tenyteny Boma, Lomeyan Payam, Kapoeta North
Description: 1.	On 24 January, three secondary sources reported that on 23 January, armed Buya youths shot and killed three male civilians (ages 27, 30, and 32 years old) and injured two others (ages 26 and 35 years old), all from the Toposa community, during a cattle raid in Tenyteny Boma, Lomeyan Payam, Kapoeta North County. According to the sources, a group of four armed Buya youths attacked and opened fire on a group of seven unarmed Toposa cattle herders while they had taken their cattle to a water point at Lotelei Kraal, Tenyteny Boma, killing three and injuring two. Reportedly, two of the herdsmen escaped unharmed and alerted the local Toposa youths who pursued the armed Buya youths and recovered the 200 heads of cattle which had been raided by the attackers. The injured victims were reportedly evacuated to a health care facility in Riwoto for medical treatment. The incident was reported at Riwoto Police Station and an investigation is reportedly underway.

Description: 1.	On 24 January, three secondary sources reported that on 23 January, armed Buya youths shot and killed three male civilians (ages 27, 30, and 32 years old) and injured two others (ages 26 and 35 years old), all from the Toposa community, during a cattle raid in Tenyteny Boma, Lomeyan Payam, Kapoeta North County. Location of Incident: Gakdong Boma, Dengjok Payam, Akobo
Description: 2.	On 24 January, multiple sources reported that on 22 January, Murle armed elements shot and killed two male civilians from the Lou Nuer community in Gakdong Boma, Dengjok Payam, Akobo County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements attacked and opened fire on the victim while they went out to fish in a nearby river in Gakdong Boma, killing them. Reportedly, passersby alerted the  local authorities who subsequently covered the bodies of the victims.

Location of Incident: Tonj Town, Tonj Payam, Tonj South
Description: 3.	On 25 January, three secondary sources reported that on the same day, one SSPDF soldier shot and killed one male civilian (a Sudanese national) in Tonj Town, Tonj Payam, Tonj South County. As recounted by the sources, the SSPDF soldier went to the victim's restaurant to have lunch and subsequently requested for the bill, which was 7,500 South Sudan Pounds (SSP). The SSPDF soldier reportedly said he only had 7,000 SSP and the restaurant owner said he could pay the 500 SSP at a later time; however, the SSPDF soldier opened fire on the Sudanese national, killing him. The sources further informed that the SSPDF soldier was subsequently apprehended and held in police custody in Tonj Payam pending investigation.

Location of Incident: Tonj Town, Tonj Payam, Tonj South
Description:
4.	On 25 January, multiple sources reported that on the same day, joint security forces extrajudicially executed one SSPDF soldier in Tonj Town, Tonj Payam, Tonj South County. According to the sources, the joint security forces extracted the SSPDF soldier from police detention in Tonj Payam, where he had been detained for killing a Sudanese national (see paragraph 3 above) and transferred him to the outskirts of Tonj Town where he was reportedly executed. 

Comment: Notably, this is the third incident of extrajudicial executions with seven victims documented in Warrap State since 1 January 2025 [see HRD Daily Reports of 13 and 14 January 2024].

Location of Incident: Lomeyan Boma, Lomeyan Payam, Kapoeta North
Description: 1.	On 27 January, three secondary sources reported that on 25 January, armed Buya youths from Kimotong Payam, Budi County attacked and killed one 14-year-old boy from the Toposa community during an attempted cattle raid in Lomeyan Boma, Lomeyan Payam, Kapoeta North County. According to the sources, the assailants attacked the victim while he was tending to calves, slit his throat to prevent him from raising an alarm, and thereafter fled the scene. The incident was reported at Riwoto Polica Station and investigations are reportedly ongoing.

Location of Incident: Panyang Payam, Duk
Description: 2.	On 27 January, multiple sources reported that on 21 January, Murle armed elements shot and killed one 33-year-old male civilian (a youth leader) from the Lou Nuer community in Panyang Payam, Duk County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements ambushed and opened fire on a group of six Lou Nuer fishermen as they were returning from fishing in Poktap Boma, Ageer Payam, killing one, while the other five escaped unharmed.

Location of Incident: Palek village, Thiet Payam, Tonj South
Description:
3.	On 27 January, three secondary sources reported that on 25 January, armed Dinka Thony youths shot and killed three male civilians and injured two others, all from the Dinka Apuk Juwiir community in Palek village, Thiet Payam, Tonj South County. According to the sources, armed Dinka Thony youths attacked and opened fire indiscriminately on the victims who were fishing in the Toch area in Palek Village, killing three and injuring two others. The injured victims were evacuated to a health care facility in Thiet Payam for medical treatment.

Comment: According to the sources, the attack was a revenge action linked to unresolved grievances between the Dinka Apuk Juwiir and Dinka Thony. Tension is reportedly mounting between the two communities with the likelihood of more revenge violence.

Location of Incident: Palek village, Thiet Payam, Tonj South
Description:
3.	On 27 January, three secondary sources reported that on 25 January, armed Dinka Thony youths shot and killed three male civilians and injured two others, all from the Dinka Apuk Juwiir community in Palek village, Thiet Payam, Tonj South County. According to the sources, armed Dinka Thony youths attacked and opened fire indiscriminately on the victims who were fishing in the Toch area in Palek Village, killing three and injuring two others. Location of Incident: Athiengpuol village, Akop Payam, Tonj North
Description:
4.	On 27 January, three secondary sources reported that on 24 January, one armed Dinka Reng youth shot and killed one male civilian from the Dinka Aduet community in Athiengpuol village, Akop Payam, Tonj North County. According to the sources, the assailant opened fire on the victim at their homestead, killing him, reportedly for impregnating his sister. The incident has reportedly heightened tensions between the Dinka Reng and Dinka Aduet sub-clans of Dinka Apuk Padoc community, with the likelihood of more retaliatory violence.

Comment: HRD will engage with the local authorities to avert further violence.

Location of Incident: Lotimor Boma, Lotimor Payam, Kapoeta East
Description: 1.	On 28 January, three secondary sources reported that on 22 January, armed Komo (Kwama) youths from Western Ethiopia, stabbed and killed two boys (ages 15 and 16 years old) from the Toposa community during a cattle raid in Lotimor Boma, Lotimor Payam, Kapoeta East County. According to the sources, armed Komo youths stormed a grazing area in Lotimor Boma, abducted the two boys as well as raided 30 heads of cattle. Reportedly, as the attackers left the area, the victims screamed for help and the attackers stabbed them to death. The incident was reported to the police in Narus Payam and investigations are reportedly underway.

Location of Incident: Lotimor Boma, Lotimor Payam, Kapoeta East
Description: 1.	On 28 January, three secondary sources reported that on 22 January, armed Komo (Kwama) youths from Western Ethiopia, stabbed and killed two boys (ages 15 and 16 years old) from the Toposa community during a cattle raid in Lotimor Boma, Lotimor Payam, Kapoeta East County. According to the sources, armed Komo youths stormed a grazing area in Lotimor Boma, abducted the two boys as well as raided 30 heads of cattle. The incident was reported to the police in Narus Payam and investigations are reportedly underway.

Location of Incident: Adeer village, Alabek Payam, Tonj North
Description:
2.	On 28 January, one secondary source reported that on 26 December, suspected armed Dinka Pan-Kuei youths allegedly gangraped a 23-year-old female civilian from the Dinka Juir in Adeer village, Alabek Payam, Tonj North County. According to the source, three Dinka Pan-Kuei youths attacked and gangraped the victim in her homestead in Adeer village, and thereafter fled to Akok Boma. Reportedly, the victim was evacuated by her relatives to a health care facility in Wau, Western Bahr el Ghazal for medical treatment. The sources further informed that the three suspects were apprehended and detained by the Police in Akok Boma.

Comment: HRD will follow up to gather more information on the incident.

Location of Incident: Ras-Olo Payam, Miridi
Description:
3.	On 28 January, multiple sources reported that on 26 January, the SSPDF arbitrarily arrested, detained and illtreated one male civilian in Ras-Olo Payam, Miridi County. According to the sources, the SSPDF arrested the victim from a local market on accusations of him being an informant for the National Salvation Front (NAS) and detained him at the SSPDF base in the area, where he has been reportedly subjected to beatings and other forms of ill-treatment. Reportedly, a local community leader is engaging with the SSPDF commander to secure his release.

Comment: HRD will to follow-up with the authorities on due process.

Location of Incident: Tore-Wandi Boma, Bangolo Payam, Mundri West
Description:
4.	On 28 January, multiple sources reported that on 20 January, armed Ambororo cattle keepers raped one female civilian in Tore-Wandi Boma, Bangolo Payam, Mundri West County. According to the sources, the perpetrators ambushed the victim while she was on her way to her farm, proceeded to rape her, and thereafter fled the area. Reportedly, the victim is yet to receive medical attention and a case has not been opened with the police.

Comment: HRD will engage the Protection Cluster and GBV subcluster partners to provide support to the survivor as well as engage with the police to investigate the incident.

Location of Incident: Tore Boma, Bangolo Payam, Mundri West
Description:
5.	On 28 January, multiple sources reported that on 18 January, armed Ambororo cattle keepers shot and killed one male civilian (a fisherman) and abducted two others, all from the Moru community, in Tore Boma, Bangolo Payam, Mundri West County.  According to the sources, the assailants opened fire on the victims at a fishing point following an altercation, killing one and abducted the other two.  Reportedly, the abducted victims subsequently escaped from the assailants. 

Comment: The incident has reportedly exacerbated the pre-existing tense situation in the area, where the presence of cattle keepers in Wandi, Moba, Diko, Bangolo, and Ladiwa Bomas has been a point of contention, as well as prompted the mobilization of local youths, the SSPDF, and the Sudan People's Liberation Army – In Opposition (SPLA-IO) to join forces to repel the cattle keepers.

Location of Incident: Tore Boma, Bangolo Payam, Mundri West
Description:
5. Location of Incident: Moribongo village, Wudabi Payam, Morobo
Description:
1.	On 29 January, three secondary sources reported that on 7 January, NAS elements abducted and killed one 35-year-old male civilian (a traditional leader) in Moribongo village, Wudabi Payam, Morobo County. According to the sources, NAS elements abducted the victim from his homestead close to the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and transferred him to Moribongo village where he was killed for unknown reasons.

Comment: According to the sources, the SSPDF recently withdrew from the area along the border with DRC to their bases Godo and Wudabi, and the civilians have since deserted the village and fled to DRC due to insecurity.

Location of Incident: Lado Payam, Juba
Description:
2.	On 29 January, two secondary sources reported that on 27 December 2024, the SSPDF arbitrarily arrested and detained four women and one man from the Bari community in Lado Payam, Juba County. According to the sources, the SSPDF arrested the four women while they were on their way to collect firewood when they were arrested by SSPDF soldiers and detained them at the checkpoint in Lado Payam for four hours. The women were allegedly subjected to sexual assault during their detention. The sources further informed that the male civilian was arrested from a different location (exact location unspecified) and detained at the same checkpoint, where he was reportedly subjected to cruel and inhumane treatment. The victims were subsequently released.

Comment: HRD will follow up to investigate the allegations.

Location of Incident: Lopuuru Boma, Kauto Payam, Kapoeta East
Description:
3.	On 29 January, three secondary sources reported that on 25 January, Murle armed elements from Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) shot and killed two male civilians (ages 25 and 27 years old) from the Toposa community during a cattle raid in Lopuuru Boma, Kauto Payam, Kapoeta East County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements attacked Lopuuru Boma and opened fire on two cattle keepers, killing them. The attackers also seized 67 heads of cattle and thereafter fled towards GPAA. Reportedly, the Toposa youths mobilized and pursued the assailants to no avail. The incident was reported the police in Narus County and investigations are reportedly ongoing.

Comment: According to the sources, tension is mounting in Kauto Payam with heightened concerns of imminent large scale attack by the Murle against the Toposa community in the area.

Location of Incident: Lopuuru Boma, Kauto Payam, Kapoeta East
Description:

Location of Incident: Kaikuny, Diro Payam, Akobo
Description: 4.	On 29 January, multiple sources reported that on 28 January, Murle armed elements attacked and injured one female civilian and abducted another from the Lou Nuer community in Kaikuny, Diro Payam, Akobo County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements attacked the victims while they had gone to collect firewood in the bushes, stabbed and injured one and abducted the other. The injured woman was reportedly evacuated to a health care facility in Kaikuny for medical treatment. The whereabouts of the abducted victim remains unknown.

Location of Incident: Kaikuny, Diro Payam, Akobo
Description: 4.	On 29 January, multiple sources reported that on 28 January, Murle armed elements attacked and injured one female civilian and abducted another from the Lou Nuer community in Kaikuny, Diro Payam, Akobo County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements attacked the victims while they had gone to collect firewood in the bushes, stabbed and injured one and abducted the other. The injured woman was reportedly evacuated to a health care facility in Kaikuny for medical treatment. The whereabouts of the abducted victim remains unknown.

Location of Incident: Thonyor, Leer
Description:
6.	On 29 January, one secondary source provided preliminary information that on 24 January, an unidentified armed element shot and killed one female civilian from the Duk Nuer community in Thonyor Payam, Leer County. According to the source, the assailant opened fire on the victim while she was walking to her home, killing her. The motive for the killing remains unknown.

Comment: HRD will follow up to gather more information on this incident.

Location of Incident: Ngero village, Kirik Payam, Tonj North
Description:
7.	On 29 January, three secondary sources reported that on 27 January, three male civilians were shot and killed (two from the Dinka Noi community and one from the Dinka Ajak Leer community) and six others were injured (four Dinka Noi and the Dinka Ajak Leer) during cattle-related violence in Ngero village, Kirik Payam, Tonj North County. According to the sources, armed Dinka Noi youths from Awul Payam attacked the Dinka Ajak Leer community in Kirik Payam, reportedly in revenge for unresolved grievances between the two communities, and in the ensuing confrontation, three civilians were killed and six others were injured. The armed Dinka Noi youths reportedly also raided 200 heads of cattle. The injured Dinka Noi civilians were evacuated to a health care facility in Warrap Town, while those from the Dinka Ajak Leer community were taken to a health care facility in Kirik Payam for medical treatment.

Comment: Tension is reportedly mounting in Kirik Payam with the likelihood of more retaliatory violence between the two sub-clans in the absence of proactive measures by the local authorities to deescalate the situation.

Location of Incident: Ngero village, Kirik Payam, Tonj North
Description:
7.	On 29 January, three secondary sources reported that on 27 January, three male civilians were shot and killed (two from the Dinka Noi community and one from the Dinka Ajak Leer community) and six others were injured (four Dinka Noi and the Dinka Ajak Leer) during cattle-related violence in Ngero village, Kirik Payam, Tonj North County. According to the sources, armed Dinka Noi youths from Awul Payam attacked the Dinka Ajak Leer community in Kirik Payam, reportedly in revenge for unresolved grievances between the two communities, and in the ensuing confrontation, three civilians were killed and six others were injured. Location of Incident: Mayen Ador village, Wunlit Payam, Tonj East
Description:
8.	On 29 January, three secondary sources reported that on 28 January, armed Dinka Luanyjang youths from Makuac Payam shot and killed one male civilian from the Dinka Ador community in Mayen Ador village, Wunlit Payam, Tonj East County. According to the sources, armed Dinka Luanyjang youths attacked and opened fire on the victim at his homestead, killing him. The attackers also seized the victim’s 20 heads of cattle.

Comment: According to the sources, the attack was a revenge action linked to unresolved grievances between the Dinka Luanyjang and Dinka Ador communities. HRD will engage with the local authorities to take proactive measures to avert more violence.

Location of Incident: Mayen Ador village, Wunlit Payam, Tonj East
Description:
8.	On 29 January, three secondary sources reported that on 28 January, armed Dinka Luanyjang youths from Makuac Payam shot and killed one male civilian from the Dinka Ador community in Mayen Ador village, Wunlit Payam, Tonj East County. According to the sources, armed Dinka Luanyjang youths attacked and opened fire on the victim at his homestead, killing him. The attackers also seized the victim’s 20 heads of cattle.

Comment: According to the sources, the attack was a revenge action linked to unresolved grievances between the Dinka Luanyjang and Dinka Ador communities. HRD will engage with the local authorities to take proactive measures to avert more violence.

Location of Incident: Mariik village, Ngabagok Payam, Tonj East
Description:
1.	On 30 January, three secondary sources reported that on the evening of 29 January, armed Dinka Thiik youths from Malual Chum Payam shot and killed one male civilian from the Dinka Akook community in Mariik village, Ngabagok Payam, Tonj East County. According to the sources, armed Dinka Thiik youths attacked and opened fire on the victim while he was sleeping in his house, killing him and thereafter fled the scene. Reportedly, the attack was a revenge action linked to past grievances between the Dinka Thiik and Dinka Akook communities. In retaliation, on 30 January, armed Dinka Akook youths attacked the Dinka Thiik community and fighting was ongoing by the time of reporting.

Comment: HRD will continue to monitor the situation and ascertain civilian casualties.

Location of Incident: Mariik village, Ngabagok Payam, Tonj East
Description:
1.
