Location of Incident: ) from the Balanda community at the Bou River Bridge in Nagero Payam, Tambura County, Western Equatoria State
Description: 5.	On 19 September, three secondary sources reported that on 3 September, one SSPDF soldier shot and killed a 38-year-old male civilian (a motorcycle rider and resident of the Baggari Jedid area in Wau Town) from the Balanda community at the Bou River Bridge in Nagero Payam, Tambura County, Western Equatoria State. According to the sources, the SSPDF soldier, stationed at the Bou River Bridge, opened fire on the victim while he was traveling on a motorcycle from Wau to Tambura County, killing him. The motive for the attack remains unknown.

Location of Incident: Kergulu village, Otogo Payam, Yei River
Description:
1.	On 22 September, two secondary sources reported that on 14 September, one suspected SSPDF soldier raped a 22-year-old female civilian from the Kakwa community in Kergulu village, Otogo Payam, Yei River County. According to the sources, the suspected SSPDF soldier accosted physically assaulted the survivor when she attempted to resist being raped. On 15 September, the survivor received medical care at a health care facility in the area. The incident was not reported to the police for unclear reasons.

Comment: The incident reportedly occurred close to the SSPDF outpost and the area has been allegedly registering an increase in rape cases attributed to SSPDF soldiers. The issue has been brought to the attention of SSPDF leadership in Yei River County.

Location of Incident: Ngarich Boma Kimotong Payam, Budi
Description: 2.	On 22 September, three secondary sources reported that on 20 September, armed Toposa elements from Katiko Payam, Kapoeta South County shot and killed one 17-year-old female civilian from the Buya community in Ngarich Boma Kimotong Payam, Budi County. According to the sources, a group of six armed Toposa elements stormed the gold mine area in Ngarich Boma and opened fire on a group of five female civilians from the Buya community enroute to the  gold mine, killing the 17-year-old girl, while the other four escaped unhurt. The attack was reportedly a revenge action for the killing of a 30-year-old male civilian from the Toposa community by armed Buya elements in Camp 15, Loriyok Boma, Kimotong Payam on 5 June 2025 [see HRD Daily Report 20 June 2025]. The incident was reported at the Loriyok Police Station and investigation is reportedly underway.

Location of Incident: Naliel Boma, Narus Payam, Kapoeta East
Description: 3.	On 18 and 19 September, three secondary sources reported that on 7 September, Murle armed elements from the Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) shot and killed two male civilians (25 and 29 years old) from the Toposa community in Naliel Boma, Narus Payam, Kapoeta East County. According to the sources, a group of six Murle armed elements, who had infiltrated the bushes of Naliel Boma allegedly with the intention of abducting children, opened fire on the victims to prevent them from raising an alarm, and thereafter fled towards the GPAA. The incident was reported at Narus Police Station and investigation is reportedly ongoing.

Location of Incident: Ameth-Chok village, Manyangok Payam, Tonj South
Description:
4.	On 22 September, three primary sources reported that on 20 September, armed Dinka Gok elements from Cueibet County, Lakes State abducted one boy from the Dinka Thony community during a cattle raid in Ameth-Chok village, Manyangok Payam, Tonj South County. As recounted by the sources, the armed Dinka Gok elements attacked Ameth-Chok village and abducted the minor who was grazing cattle in the area. The attackers also seized 30 heads of cattle and fled back  into Lakes State. the sources further informed that, later on the same day, the attackers released the abductee who was able to trace his way back home in Ameth-Chok village, as was physically unharmed.

Comment: The incident occurred within the context of cross-border cattle-related violence and retaliation for past violence/unresolved grievances between communities.

Location of Incident: Ameth-Chok village, Manyangok Payam, Tonj South
Description:
4. As recounted by the sources, the armed Dinka Gok elements attacked Ameth-Chok village and abducted the minor who was grazing cattle in the area. The attackers also seized 30 heads of cattle and fled back  into Lakes State. the sources further informed that, later on the same day, the attackers released the abductee who was able to trace his way back home in Ameth-Chok village, as was physically unharmed.

Comment: The incident occurred within the context of cross-border cattle-related violence and retaliation for past violence/unresolved grievances between communities.

Location of Incident: the Thurgung Bridge in Marial Bai Payam, Jur River
Description:
5.	On 22 September, two secondary sources reported that on 18 September, a SSPDF soldier shot and injured one 35-year-old male civilian (a Somali national and commercial truck driver)) at the Thurgung Bridge in Marial Bai Payam, Jur River County. According to the sources, the SSPDF soldier stationed at the Thurgung Bridge opened fire on the victim while he was traveling from Kuajok to Wau, injuring him, for unknown reason. On 19 September, the victim was taken to a hospital in Wau for medical treatment and subsequently evacuated to Juba for advanced medical care. A case has been filed at Wau Town Police Station; however, the perpetrator is yet to be apprehended.

Comment: The incident raises concerns about the safety of civilians and their right to free movement, as well as highlights the urgent need for accountability and measures to protect civilians from unprovoked acts of violence by security personnel. HRD will follow up on the case for accountability.

Location of Incident: Yambio Town, Yambio
Description: 6.	On 22 September, a primary source reported that on 18 September, NSS personnel arbitrarily arrested and detained one 18-year-old male civilian from the Azande community in Yambio Town, Yambio County. As recounted by the source, three NSS personnel arrested the victim at his home in Akorogbodi-1 residential area in Yambio Town and transferred him to the NSS detention facility, where he was held in a dark room with inadequate ventilation. The source further informed that the victim received minimal food once daily, and no information was provided to him on the charges against him violating his fundamental rights to information, fair treatment, and humane detention as protected under national and international human rights law.

Location of Incident: Hafiye Boma, Iyire Payam, Torit
Description: 1.	On 23 September, three secondary sources reported that on 10 September, SPLA-IO elements unlawfully detained and ill-treated one male civilian (Payam Administrator) in Hafiye Boma, Iyire Payam, Torit County. According to the sources, the SPLA-IO elements, on the instructions of their commander, arrested the victim while he was addressing issues in one of the five Bomas of Iyire Payam under his administrative control and supervision and detained him at their detention facility. The victim was subsequently brought before the SPLA-IO Commander who questioned his presence in Hafiye Boma, insisting that Hafiye Boma was now under SPLA-IO control and that government officials are not allowed in the Boma. The victim was also accused of attempting to spy on the SPLA-IO, an accusation he denied. Reportedly, the SPLA-IO Commander thereafter ordered his soldiers to beat him up before being released in the evening of the same day without any formal charge. The incident was reported to the state authorities in Torit.

Location of Incident: Tambura Town, Tambura
Description:
2.	On 23 September, multiple sources reported that on 19 and 21 September, suspected SPLA-IO elements abducted four civilians including one woman and two children in Tambura Town, Tambura County. According to the sources, on 19 September, suspected SPLA-IO elements abducted one 35-year-old man and a 28-year-old woman near the River Yubu bridge along the Namutima-Tambura road while they were traveling from an Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) camp in Tambura Town to their family farm. The armed elements reportedly demanded an undisclosed ransom from the victims' families via phone calls. Similarly, on 21 September, suspected SPLA-IO elements abducted two boys (12 and 14 years old) along the Tambura-Source Yubu road in Giara village as they were returning home from Tambura center where they had gone to purchase school supplies. The whereabouts of the abductees remains unknown. 

Comment: These incidents underscore the urgent need for enhanced protection and security measures for civilians in Tambura County.

Location of Incident: Mundu Boma, Kupera Payam, Lainya County
Description:
Rape of two minors by two civilian men in Mundu Boma, Kupera Payam, Lainya County
On 15 August 2025, HRD YFO received and documented information from multiple reliable sources including a police officer and two community leaders regarding the rape of two minors aged 14 and 15 years (details on file) respectively from Pojulu tribe by two civilian men in Mundu Boma, Kupera Payam, Lainya County on 11 August 2025. 
According to the sources, at around 5:00 pm on 11 August 2025, the two civilian men, both timber loggers, were returning from Wuji Payam, Lainya County to Yei Town after work. The two men; aged 27-years-old South Sudanese national and 21-years-old Ugandan national respectively met the two adolescent girls walking along the road to their home and offered them free transportation. However, the two men diverted the young girls into a dark teak forest where they threatened them with a pistol and subsequently forced them further into the bushes where each perpetrator raped one girl.  Sources   further reported, the 15-year-old (details on file) was raped by the 27-year-old South Sudanese (details on file) while the 14-year-old (details on file) was raped by the 21-year-old Ugandan (details on file). After the gruesome incident, the perpetrators escaped towards Yei Town.  The survivors reported to one of health facilities in areas for medical care.  Both perpetrators were arrested and brought to the police station in Yei Town for further investigations on 12 August 2025.  However, during the arrest police did not find the perpetrators in possession of any firearm.
Comments:  HRD – FYO notes that the threat of a pistol in civilian hands reflect broader insecurity and lawlessness exacerbated by the lingering effects of armed conflict in South Sudan. Women and girls, particularly minors, remain disproportionately vulnerable to sexual violence in Greater Yei. The South Sudan Penal Code Act, 2008 prohibits rape and sexual assault (Sections 247–248). The act constitutes rape and attempted rape, both criminal offenses. The Child Act, 2008 prohibits sexual abuse of minors, including any form of assault or exploitation. The Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC): Obligates protection from all forms of sexual exploitation (Articles 19 and 34).

Location of Incident: Raja Prison, Raja County
Description:
A 16-year-old girl was indefinitely detained in Raja Prison, Raja County, for refusing a forced marriage. 
On 20 August 2025, during a monitoring visit to Raja Prison, HRD interviewed a 16-year-old female civilian from the Banda community who reported that she had been forced into marriage by her family against her will. She stated that she refused to live with her husband; as a result, her family arranged for her detention until she could repay the marriage dowry, estimated at six million South Sudanese Pounds (SSP), which her relatives had already received. The survivor expressed distress over her situation and described the practice as profoundly unjust. HRD also received corroborating information from multiple independent sources confirming that forced and early marriages are widespread and a deep-rooted practice in Raja County, often leaving young girls vulnerable to abuse and denial of education. 
Comments: HRD will follow up on the case to ensure the release of the survivor and advocate to end such harmful traditional practices.

Location of Incident: Naliel Boma, Narus Payam, Kapoeta East
Description: 1.	On 24 September, three secondary sources reported that on 9 September, Murle armed elements shot and killed one 30-year-old male civilian from the Toposa community in Naliel Boma, Narus Payam, Kapoeta East County. According to the sources, a group of five Murle armed elements infiltrated Naliel Boma and opened fire on the victim while he was taking bath in a river in the area. Reportedly, the motive for the killing was to prevent the victim from raising an alarm to alert the Toposa youths to repel the impending attack. The incident was reported at Narus Police Station and investigation is reportedly ongoing.

Location of Incident: Isalaro Boma, Kudo Payam, Torit
Description: 2.	On 24 September, multiple sources reported that on 20 September, suspected SPLA-IO elements attacked and ill-treated two civilians and killed another in Isalaro Boma, Kudo Payam, Torit County. As recounted by the sources, a group of approximately 50 suspected of SPLA-IO elements ambushed and attacked two civilians and subsequently opened fire on the driver of the Torit State Prison who was travelling from Torit to the Prison farm in Isalaro Boma, killing him. Reportedly, the SPLA-IO elements opened fire on the victim when he attempted to rescue the two civilians who were being extorted and ill-treated by the by the SPLA-IO armed elements. The Police and the National Security Service (NSS) were reportedly deployed at the scene; however, no suspects were apprehended. The two victims subsequently received medical treatment at a hospital in Torit.

Location of Incident: Isalaro Boma, Kudo Payam, Torit
Description: 2.	On 24 September, multiple sources reported that on 20 September, suspected SPLA-IO elements attacked and ill-treated two civilians and killed another in Isalaro Boma, Kudo Payam, Torit County. As recounted by the sources, a group of approximately 50 suspected of SPLA-IO elements ambushed and attacked two civilians and subsequently opened fire on the driver of the Torit State Prison who was travelling from Torit to the Prison farm in Isalaro Boma, killing him. Reportedly, the SPLA-IO elements opened fire on the victim when he attempted to rescue the two civilians who were being extorted and ill-treated by the by the SPLA-IO armed elements. The Police and the National Security Service (NSS) were reportedly deployed at the scene; however, no suspects were apprehended. The two victims subsequently received medical treatment at a hospital in Torit.

Location of Incident: Thio village, Pathuon West Payam, Gogrial East
Description:
3.	On 24 September, three primary sources reported that on 19 September, armed Nuer elements from Mayom County, Unity State shot and injured one male civilian from the Dinka Apuk community Thio village, Pathuon West Payam, Gogrial East County. As recounted by the sources, the armed Nuer elements attacked and opened fire on the victim in his homestead, injuring him. Reportedly, the armed Dinka Apuk youths repulsed the attackers who fled back into Unity State. The injured victim is reportedly receiving medical treatment at a health care facility in Luanyaker Town, Pathuon West Payam. 

Comment: The attack was reportedly a revenge action for past violence/unresolved grievances in the context of cross-border violence involving communities along the Warrap-Unity State border.

Location of Incident: Yambio Town, Yambio
Description:
4.	On 24 September, two secondary sources reported that on 20 September, joint security forces arbitrarily arrested and ill-treated one 29-year-old male civilian (a trader) from the Azande community in Yambio Town, Yambio County. According to the sources,  personnel of joint security forces stationed at the Masia Police Station compound arrested the victim from shop at Masia market in Yambio Town and transferred him to the old Masia Police Station, where he was repeatedly beaten. Reportedly, the victim was arrested following a misunderstanding with his neighbour at the Masia market. The sources further informed that the soldiers demanded and received a fine of 1,000,000 (one million) South Sudanese Pounds (SSP) from the victim before releasing him on 22 September. The victim subsequently received medical treatment at a hospital in Yambio Town and thereafter filed a complaint with the Public Prosecution Attorney in Yambio.

Comments: The use of the old Masia Police Station by the organized forces poses significant concerns regarding arbitrary arrest of civilians and human rights abuses. Furthermore, the co-location of organized forces within the compound designated for civilian policing undermines the distinction between civilian law enforcement and military operations. This blurring of roles increases the risk of unlawful deprivation of liberty, excessive use of force, and ill treatment of detainees and other forms of human rights violations.

Location of Incident: Balamuke Village, Nyarju Sub-Boma, Otogo Payam, Yei River
Description: 1.	On 25 September, two secondary sources reported that on 21 September, suspected NAS elements abducted three male civilians in Balamuke Village, Nyarju Sub-Boma, Otogo Payam, Yei River County. According to the sources, the suspected NAS elements abducted the three civilians from separate locations in the same village around as they were returning from their different livelihood activities including farming. The suspected NAS elements reportedly coerced the abductees to carry items in sacks and bags that included food and military supplies to their in Udabi Payam, Morobo country. The abductees were released on 22 September.

Location of Incident: Kapoeta Municipality, Kapoeta South
Description: 2.	On 25 September, multiple sources reported that on the same day, two civilians (25 and 27 years old) from the Toposa community were shot and injured during an attack on the office of the National Security Service (NSS) and South Sudan People’s Defence Forces (SSPDF) barracks by armed elements suspected to be affiliated to the SPLA-IO in Kapoeta Municipality, Kapoeta South County. According to the sources, a group of 10 armed elements suspected to be affiliated with the SPLA-IO attacked the NSS office and SSPDF barracks in Kapoeta South Municipal Town Council, and in the ensuing confrontation, two civilians were injured. Reportedly, seven other individuals were also injured during the fighting. The special military forces were reportedly deployed from Juba to reinforce the government forces in Kapoeta. The injured victims were evacuated to a hospital in Kapoeta for medical treatment.

Location of Incident: Kapoeta Municipality, Kapoeta South
Description: 2.	On 25 September, multiple sources reported that on the same day, two civilians (25 and 27 years old) from the Toposa community were shot and injured during an attack on the office of the National Security Service (NSS) and South Sudan People’s Defence Forces (SSPDF) barracks by armed elements suspected to be affiliated to the SPLA-IO in Kapoeta Municipality, Kapoeta South County. According to the sources, a group of 10 armed elements suspected to be affiliated with the SPLA-IO attacked the NSS office and SSPDF barracks in Kapoeta South Municipal Town Council, and in the ensuing confrontation, two civilians were injured. Reportedly, seven other individuals were also injured during the fighting. The special military forces were reportedly deployed from Juba to reinforce the government forces in Kapoeta. The injured victims were evacuated to a hospital in Kapoeta for medical treatment.

Location of Incident: Dangar village, Ngapagok Payam, Tonj East
Description:
3.	On 25 September, four primary sources reported that on 14 September, the SSPDF extrajudicially executed four male civilians (two Dinka Luanyjang and two Dinka Akook)  in Dangar village, Ngapagok Payam, Tonj East County. As recounted by the sources, on 15 August 2025, the victims and others still at large ambushed the convoy of the Acting Commissioner of Tonj East County in Ngabagok Payam, and in the ensuing confrontation with the Commissioner’s security detail, the four individuals were arrested and detained at Ngabagok Police Station. Reportedly, on 14 September, SSPDF personnel, on the orders of a senior County official, extracted the victims from Ngabagok Police Station and transferred them to Dangar village where they were executed by firing squad. The bodies of the victims were reportedly handed over to their families the next day for interment.

Comment: The victims were reportedly part of the armed gang that was ambushing, robbing and harassing travelers along the Thiet-Romic road.

Location of Incident: Ekana village, Mapel Payam, Jur River
Description: 4.	On 24 September, multiple sources reported that on the same day, suspected Dinka Yar armed elements from Warrap State shot and killed one 17-year-old boy in Ekana village, Mapel Payam, Jur River County. According to the sources, a group of five suspected Dinka Yar armed elements attacked and opened fire on the victim while he was going to his farm, killing him. The incident was reported to the SSPDF stationed at the Mapel junction checkpoint who pursued the attackers. Reportedly, two of the suspects were apprehended and detained in Awat Boma, Warrap State, while the other three remain at large.

Location of Incident: St. Mary’s Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) camp in Tambura Town, Tambura County
Description: 5.	On 25 September, two secondary sources reported that on 24 September, an unidentified armed element shot and injured a 15-year-old girl from the Azande community at St. Mary’s Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) camp in Tambura Town, Tambura County. According to the sources, the armed assailant broke into the homestead of the victim and in the ensuing altercation with the victim’s father, the minor was shot and injured. The motive for the attack remains unknown. The incident was reported to the police; however, no suspect has been apprehended yet. The injured victim is reportedly receiving medical treatment at a health care facility in Tambura Town.

Location of Incident: Kediba Payam, Mundri East
Description: 6.	On 25 September, multiple sources reported that on 24 September, two civilians from the Moru community were shot and injured during an attack by suspected SPLA-IO and NAS elements on the SSPDF base in Kediba Payam, Mundri East County. According to the sources, the armed elements attacked and momentarily overran the SSPDF base, during which two civilians were injured. Reportedly, the SSPDF subsequently reinforced and recaptured the base. The attack reportedly resulted in the displacement of thousands of civilians to Lui Payam and the surrounding areas. The injured victims were evacuated to a hospital in Lui for medical treatment.

Location of Incident: Tambura Town, Tambura County
Description: 7.	On 25 September, two secondary sources reported that on 24 September, the SSPDF arbitrarily arrested and detained one civilian (IDP camp manager) in Tambura Town, Tambura County. According to the sources, the arrest followed an incident in which armed elements looted stores located in front of the IDP camp in Tambura Town. Reportedly, when the SSPDF soldiers pursued the armed elements, they allegedly fled into the IDP camp adjacent to the TOB. Consequently, the SSPDF soldiers arrested the camp manager, allegedly in proxy, on suspicion that he may have knowledge of the armed elements. Reportedly, the family of the victim has been denied access to him.

Location of Incident: both from the Lotuko community, in Lobira Boma, Chahari Payam, Ikotos County
Description: 1.	On 25 and 26 September, three secondary sources reported that on 24 September, armed Buya elements from Loriyok Boma, Kimotong Payam, Budi County shot and killed one 20-year-old male civilian and injured a 19-year-old male civilian, both from the Lotuko community, in Lobira Boma, Chahari Payam, Ikotos County. According to the sources, a group of armed Buya elements intercepted and opened fire on the victims at the outskirt of Ileu Boma, Hiyala Payam, Torit County as they were on their way from Lobira Boma to Ileu Boma Square to attend a rally hosted by the Governor of Eastern Equatoria State. Reportedly, the motive for the attack was to avenge the killing of two Buya male civilians (age 26 and 30 years old) from Kimotong Payam by armed Lotuko elements during a cattle raid in Kidepo Valley River in Lobira Boma on 19 August 2024 [See HRD Daily Report 21 October 2024]. The injured victim was reportedly evacuated to a hospital in Torit for medical treatment. The incident was reported at the Chahari Police Station and investigations are reportedly ongoing.

Location of Incident: both from the Lotuko community, in Lobira Boma, Chahari Payam, Ikotos County
Description: 1.	On 25 and 26 September, three secondary sources reported that on 24 September, armed Buya elements from Loriyok Boma, Kimotong Payam, Budi County shot and killed one 20-year-old male civilian and injured a 19-year-old male civilian, both from the Lotuko community, in Lobira Boma, Chahari Payam, Ikotos County. According to the sources, a group of armed Buya elements intercepted and opened fire on the victims at the outskirt of Ileu Boma, Hiyala Payam, Torit County as they were on their way from Lobira Boma to Ileu Boma Square to attend a rally hosted by the Governor of Eastern Equatoria State. Reportedly, the motive for the attack was to avenge the killing of two Buya male civilians (age 26 and 30 years old) from Kimotong Payam by armed Lotuko elements during a cattle raid in Kidepo Valley River in Lobira Boma on 19 August 2024 [See HRD Daily Report 21 October 2024]. The injured victim was reportedly evacuated to a hospital in Torit for medical treatment. The incident was reported at the Chahari Police Station and investigations are reportedly ongoing.

Location of Incident: Marial-Adot village, Alabek Payam, Tonj North
Description:
2.	On 28 September, three primary sources reported that on 24 September, the SSPDF shot and injured one male civilian from the Dinka Lou-Ariik community during a disarmament exercise in Marial-Adot village, Alabek Payam, Tonj North County. As recounted by the sources, SSPDF personnel along with local and traditional leaders entered the homestead of the victim in Marial-Adot village and demanded that he hands over his firearm; however, the victim allegedly resisted and asked for assurances of official security for his family and livestock and the SSPDF personnel opened fire on the victim, injuring him. The SSPDF personnel allegedly entered his house and recovered the firearm. The victim was evacuated to a health care facility in Alabek Town for medical.

Comment: The incident has been viewed as “use of excessive force” by the SSPDF personnel in enforcing the disarmament. The County authority reportedly visited the area, calmed down the rising tensions, and explained that the incident was a case of misunderstanding as the forceful disarmament phase had not yet begun.

Location of Incident: Azande community in Kpotonayo village, Source-Yubu Payam, Tambura
Description: 3.	On 26 September, multiple sources reported that on 25 September, suspected SPLA-IO elements shot and killed one 60-year-old male civilian from the Azande community in Kpotonayo village, Source-Yubu Payam, Tambura County. According to the sources, the SPLA-IO elements attacked Kpotonayo village, set ablaze 13 homesteads, shot and killed one civilian, as well as looted and vandalized the Kpotonayo Primary Health Care Unit, before retreating toward Namutina Payam. The incident reportedly caused most villagers to flee into the surrounding bush for safety. The security situation reportedly remains tense in the area.

Location of Incident: Juba-Torit road in Ngangalla Boma, Liria Payam, Juba County
Description: 1.	On 29 September, multiple sources reported that on 28 September, two children (one two-year-old boy from the Lokoya community and a three-year-old from the Pojulu community), who had been abducted by Murle armed elements along the Juba-Torit road in Ngangalla Boma, Liria Payam, Juba County on 5 September, and recovered by the authorities in Gumuruk County, Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA) were transferred to Pibor Town on 28 September. According to the sources, arrangements are underway to transfer the two children to Juba for family reunification.

Location of Incident: Lobuhi Boma, Imehejek Payam, Imehejek Administrative Area.
Description: 2.	On 29 September, three secondary sources reported that on 24 September, Murle armed elements from GPAA abducted two girls (14 and 15 years old) from the Lopit community in Lobuhi Boma, Imehejek Payam, Imehejek Administrative Area. According to the sources, a group of six Murle armed elements encountered three Lopit female civilians (14, 15 and 18 years old) from Locharok Boma, Arilo Payam, Lafon County as they were walking from Locharok Boma to Imehejek, and abducted the two girls, while the 18-year-old woman escaped unharmed. The was reported to the authorities in Imehejek as well as at the Imehejek Administrative Police Station and investigation is reportedly underway.

Location of Incident: Thiam, Uror
Description: 3.	On 29 September, multiple sources reported that in June (exact date unspecified), Murle armed elements abducted a 17-year-old girl from the Lou Nuer community in Thiam, Uror County. According to the sources, Murle armed elements abducted the victim while she was on her way from Pajut, Duk County to Thiam. The whereabouts of the victim remain unknown.

Location of Incident: Tharliel village, Mankien Payam, Mayom County
Description:
4.	On 29 September, multiple sources reported that on 27 September, Bul Nuer armed elements shot and killed a 30-year-old male civilian in Tharliel village, Mankien Payam, Mayom County. According to the sources, the assailants attacked and opened fire on the victim while he was returning to his home in Tharliel village from Mankien Town. The sources indicated that the attackers were later spotted in Ajak Kach Payam, Twic County, Warrap State.

Comment: Observably, the proliferation of small arms, the lack of prompt judicial mechanisms in communities, and the absence of state institutions to address criminality continue to render civilians vulnerable to attacks by armed elements in the context of random shootings and killings, inter-/intra-communal violence and revenge killings, hence creating a vicious cycle of violence.

Location of Incident: Marial-Adot village, Alabek Payam, Tonj North
Description:
5.	On 29 September, three primary sources reported that on 27 September, the SSPDF shot and killed one male civilian (a cattle herder) in Marial-Adot village, Alabek Payam, Tonj North County. As recounted by the sources, SSPDF soldiers who were patrolling in the area encountered a group of Dinka Lou-Ariik herders as they were in grazing their cattle Marial-Adot village and reportedly ordered the herders who were carrying arms to put them down. Reportedly, as some herders dropped down their guns, one unarmed herder attempted escape prompting the SSPFDF soldiers to open fire, killing him. The SSPDF thereafter took possession of the firearms that were surrendered by the herders.

Comment: According to the sources, this is another instance of the use of excessive force by SSPDF personnel in enforcing the disarmament. Reportedly, tension has been heightened between the SSPDF and the Lou-Ariik community over this incident. The County leadership reportedly visited the area and explained the ongoing disarmament.

Location of Incident: Biem-Kat village, Ajak Kuac Payam, Twic
Description:
6.	On 29 September, three primary sources reported that on 21 September, suspected Nuer armed elements shot and killed two male civilians from the Dinka Twic Mayardit community in Biem-Kat village, Ajak Kuac Payam, Twic County. As recounted by the sources, the Nuer armed elements attacked and opened fire on a group of Dinka Twic Mayardit civilians as they were fishing at a large water point in Biem-Kat village, killing two. It is along the shared border with Unity State. The attackers also reportedly seized the fish, fishing gear, and other personal items of the victims and thereafter fled back into Unity State.

Comment: Reportedly, the attack occurred in the context of ongoing cross-border violence and revenge for past violence/unresolved grievances between communities along the Warrap-Unity border.

Location of Incident: Biem-Kat village, Ajak Kuac Payam, Twic
Description:
6.	On 29 September, three primary sources reported that on 21 September, suspected Nuer armed elements shot and killed two male civilians from the Dinka Twic Mayardit community in Biem-Kat village, Ajak Kuac Payam, Twic County. As recounted by the sources, the Nuer armed elements attacked and opened fire on a group of Dinka Twic Mayardit civilians as they were fishing at a large water point in Biem-Kat village, killing two. It is along the shared border with Unity State. The attackers also reportedly seized the fish, fishing gear, and other personal items of the victims and thereafter fled back into Unity State.

Comment: Reportedly, the attack occurred in the context of ongoing cross-border violence and revenge for past violence/unresolved grievances between communities along the Warrap-Unity border.

Location of Incident: Busseri Boma, Wau
Description:
7.	On 29 September, multiple sources reported that on 15 September, one SSPDF soldier arbitrarily arrested and detained one 45-year-old male civilian from the Furqi Community in Busseri Boma, Wau County. According to the sources, the SSPDF soldier arrested the victim at the Busseri Checkpoint Bridge, on the orders of one SSPDF officer after he requested for the removal of officer’s cattle from his farmland. Reportedly, the victim had repeatedly filed complaints at the Busseri Police Station about the destruction of his farmland by cattle belonging to the SSPDF officer; however, no action was taken, nor compensation provided. The sources further informed that on 15 September when he approached the SSPDF officer requesting the removal of the cattle from his farmland, the officer ordered his soldiers to detain him. The next day, the victim reportedly paid 80,000 South Sudan Pounds (SSP) demanded by the SSPDF officer for his release. The victim subsequently filed a case at Busseri Police Station who referred the case to Hai Kosti Police Station in Wau.

Comment: The SSPDF presence in agricultural areas such as Busseri poses serious risks to food security, undermines livelihoods, and contributes to wider patterns of civilian harm and food insecurity.

Location of Incident: Nagero Town, Nagero
Description: 8.	On 29 September, multiple sources reported that on 26 September, one 48-year-old male civilian from the Azande community was shot and injured during a confrontation between the suspected SPLA-IO elements and SSPDF in Nagero Town, Nagero County. According to the sources, suspected SPLA-IO elements attacked the SSPDF barracks in Nagero Town and in the ensuing confrontation with the SSPDF, one civilian was shot and injured in crossfire. The suspected SPLA-IO elements also reportedly vandalized and looted civilian properties, the market, and Nagero Health Care Centre. Reportedly, the entire civilian population of Nagero Town has been displaced, with many seeking refuge in the bushes without access to shelter, food, or medicine.

Location of Incident: Nagero Town, Nagero
Description: 8.	On 29 September, multiple sources reported that on 26 September, one 48-year-old male civilian from the Azande community was shot and injured during a confrontation between the suspected SPLA-IO elements and SSPDF in Nagero Town, Nagero County. According to the sources, suspected SPLA-IO elements attacked the SSPDF barracks in Nagero Town and in the ensuing confrontation with the SSPDF, one civilian was shot and injured in crossfire. The suspected SPLA-IO elements also reportedly vandalized and looted civilian properties, the market, and Nagero Health Care Centre. Reportedly, the entire civilian population of Nagero Town has been displaced, with many seeking refuge in the bushes without access to shelter, food, or medicine.

Location of Incident: Jikmir Payam, Nassir
Description: •	15 August – violent clashes between SSPDF and the White Army in Jikmir Payam, Nassir County. The White Army allegedly ambushed SSPDF personnel moving into Jikmir to collect firewood from abandoned properties. In retaliation, SSPDF forces shelled Burebiey, a predominantly civilian settlement across the Sobat River near the Ethiopian border that is hosting IDPs from Nassir and neighbouring counties. The shelling reportedly wounded 14 civilians and killed 11. 11 SSPDF personnel were killed, and 4 White Army elements were killed. The shelling is believed to have been driven by suspicions that White Army elements, who had previously clashed with the SSPDF in Jikmir, had fled to Burebiey. Ongoing monitoring to confirm casualties.

Location of Incident: Jikmir Payam, Nassir
Description: •	15 August – violent clashes between SSPDF and the White Army in Jikmir Payam, Nassir County. The White Army allegedly ambushed SSPDF personnel moving into Jikmir to collect firewood from abandoned properties. In retaliation, SSPDF forces shelled Burebiey, a predominantly civilian settlement across the Sobat River near the Ethiopian border that is hosting IDPs from Nassir and neighbouring counties. The shelling reportedly wounded 14 civilians and killed 11. 11 SSPDF personnel were killed, and 4 White Army elements were killed. The shelling is believed to have been driven by suspicions that White Army elements, who had previously clashed with the SSPDF in Jikmir, had fled to Burebiey. Ongoing monitoring to confirm casualties.

Location of Incident: Jikmir Payam, Nassir
Description: •	15 August – violent clashes between SSPDF and the White Army in Jikmir Payam, Nassir County. The White Army allegedly ambushed SSPDF personnel moving into Jikmir to collect firewood from abandoned properties. In retaliation, SSPDF forces shelled Burebiey, a predominantly civilian settlement across the Sobat River near the Ethiopian border that is hosting IDPs from Nassir and neighbouring counties. The shelling reportedly wounded 14 civilians and killed 11. 11 SSPDF personnel were killed, and 4 White Army elements were killed. The shelling is believed to have been driven by suspicions that White Army elements, who had previously clashed with the SSPDF in Jikmir, had fled to Burebiey. Ongoing monitoring to confirm casualties.

Location of Incident: Yei Town, Yei River
Description:
2.	On 30 September, two primary sources and two secondary sources reported that on 23 September, SSNPS personnel arbitrarily arrested and detained one 13-year-old girl (a victim of attempted early and forced marriage) and 24-year-old woman, both from the Dinka community,  in Yei Town, Yei River County. As recounted by the sources, the father of the 13-year-old girl had allegedly planned an early and forced marriage for her 60-year-old man; however, the victim, after learning of the plan, escaped with another man to Yirol in Lake State. the father thereafter reported the matter to the police, and traced the victim in Yirol and threatened the family that was keeping her to bring her back to Yei. On 23 September, the minor  was accompanied by another woman back to Yei, and on arrival, they were arrested by the police and detained at Yei Police Station. Reportedly, on 24 September, the Public Prosecutor sanctioned charges and demanded both at Yei County prison on charges of cohabitation.

Comment: Although the state prosecution attorney demanded the victims with a warrant to the prison, the charges imposed on the victims have no justifiable legal basis. The arresting and detaining authorities are perceived to silence the female victims from claiming their rights of rejecting forced and early marriage and perpetuates discrimination against women. Instead of arresting the ones that would be perpetrators, the police and state prosecutor have turned victims into suspects which raises serious concerns about protection of the girlchild and women. Further forced and early marriage is a human a rights violation under international law and treaties, some of which South Sudan is a party. HRD will follow up on the matter for justice, including release of victims.

Location of Incident: Kerepi Boma, Pageri Payam, Magwi
Description: 3.	On 30 September, one primary source and two secondary sources reported that on 24 September, the SSPDF arbitrarily arrested, detained, and ill-treated one civilian (a defence lawyer) in Kerepi Boma, Pageri Payam, Magwi County. As recounted by the sources, a group of 10 SSPDF soldiers from SSPDF Tiger Division Barracks in Kerepi Boma stormed the Nimule County court premises with a military vehicle and arrested the defense Lawyer as he came out of the court in Nimule Town, beat him up, forcefully dragged him into their military vehicle and drove off to SSPDF Tiger Division Barracks in Kerepi Boma where they detained him. The SSPDF soldiers reportedly accused the lawyer for intervening and appealing against the decision of the Mobile Court in Nimule which had awarded compensation against the lawyer’s client who was accused of causing the death of a soldier of the Tiger Division in a road traffic accident in Nimule, claiming that he was disrupting and prolonging the payment of the compensation through his appeal and actions. The victim was reportedly released in the morning on 25 September 2025 without charge following the intervention of his colleagues and relatives. Reportedly, the defense lawyer subsequently opened a criminal case of assault against the soldiers at Nimule Police Station.

Location of Incident: Chuilbong Payam, Ayod
Description:
4.	On 30 September, multiple sources reported that on 20 September, Lou Nuer armed elements shot and killed two male civilians and injured six others during a cattle raid in Chuilbong Payam, Ayod County. According to the sources, the Lou Nuer armed elements attacked Chuilbong Payam, killing two civilians and injuring six. The attackers also reportedly raided approximately 4,570 heads of cattle. Reportedly, three of the victims who were critically injured were airlifted by a humanitarian organization to Akobo for medical treatment. 

Comment: The County authorities reportedly intervened and dissuaded the local youth from taking retaliatory action

Location of Incident: Chuilbong Payam, Ayod
Description:
4.	On 30 September, multiple sources reported that on 20 September, Lou Nuer armed elements shot and killed two male civilians and injured six others during a cattle raid in Chuilbong Payam, Ayod County. According to the sources, the Lou Nuer armed elements attacked Chuilbong Payam, killing two civilians and injuring six. The attackers also reportedly raided approximately 4,570 heads of cattle. Reportedly, three of the victims who were critically injured were airlifted by a humanitarian organization to Akobo for medical treatment. 

Comment: The County authorities reportedly intervened and dissuaded the local youth from taking retaliatory action

Location of Incident: Matangai Payam, Rumbek Centre
Description: 5.	On 30 September, multiple sources reported that on 29 September, Dinka Agar armed elements from the Ajiek clan shot and killed one male civilian from the Dinka Agaar Boor clan in Matangai Payam, Rumbek Centre County. According to the sources, a group of Dinka Agaar armed elements attacked and opened fire on Agaalic (Abeer) cattle camp in Matangai Payam, injuring one of the occupants, who subsequently succumbed to the injury while being evacuated to a health care facility. The attack was reportedly a revenge action for long-standing  grievances between the two clans. The county authorities and the police reportedly intervened to quell the situation.

Location of Incident: Mander-Akook village, Ngabagok Payam, Tonj East
Description:
6.	On 30 September, three primary sources reported that on 28 September, joint Dinka Luanyjang and Dinka Pan-Juaj armed elements abducted two male juveniles from the Dinka Akook community during a cattle raid in Mander-Akook village, Ngabagok Payam, Tonj East County. As recounted by the sources, the Dinka Luanyjang and Dinka Pan-Juaj armed elements jointly attacked the Dinka Akook community in a cattle camp in Mander-Akook village, and abducted the two minors as they were grazing cattle in the area. The attackers also reportedly seized over 100 heads of cattle and fled with them and the victims towards Paweng and Palieng Payams. the victims were reportedly set free at the border with Palieng Payam and returned to Ngabagok.

Comment: According to the sources, the leadership of Tonj East County intervened and assisted to recover an unspecified number of cattle to the Akook community.

Location of Incident: Anuol town of Anuol Payam under Yirol West County
Description:
A 24-year-old man was arrested and detained in Mapuordit military detention facility for raping an 8-year-old girl in Anuol Payam of Yirol West County.

On 4 September 2025, HRD obtained information from one secondary source (authorities in Yirol West County) to the effect that 18 August 2025, a 24-year-old man (name on file) raped an 8-year-old girl (name on file) in Anuol town of Anuol Payam under Yirol West County. According to information gathered, the alleged perpetrator lived in the same house as the girl. On that day, while only her and other children were home, the man dragged her into a room and raped her. The girl reportedly told her aunt about the incident the same evening, after she was found to be sick. The girl was taken to Mapuordit hospital for medical care.

The source informed HRD that relatives of the girl filed a case with the Yirol town Police on 3 September 2025 and that the alleged perpetrator was arrested and taken directly to the Mapuordit military detention facility in Yirol West County where he is currently undergoing investigation. According to the source, the Public Prosecutor advised the relatives of the girl to request the SSPDF in charge of the Mapuordit military detention facility to transfer the case to Yirol town Police Station so that the case can be investigated through the proper channels and the alleged perpetrator be sent to court.

Comments: Cases of rape and other forms of GBV are commonly handled by SSPDF who arrest the suspects and bring them to military detention facilities to conduct their own investigations, taking cases away from SSNPS. Nevertheless, these investigations rarely yield justice for survivors and instead mostly results in punishment and extortion of money from the alleged perpetrators.

Location of Incident: Geri Boma, Wudabi Payam, Morobo County
Description:
•	Rape of a 3-year-old girl by a 57-year-old civilian man in Geri Boma, Wudabi Payam, Morobo County 
On 03 September 2025, HRD YFO, received information from two reliable sources including a police officer and a humanitarian worker regarding the rape of a 3-year-old girl (details on file) by a 57-year-old civilian man in Geri Boma, Wudabi Payam, Morobo County on 15 April 2025. 

Sources reported that in the afternoon of 15 April 2025, a 57-year-old (details on file) from the Keliko tribe paid a visit to his neighbor in Geri Boma, Wudabi Payam, Morobo County. According to the sources, the perpetrator, reportedly intoxicated at the time, took advantage of the child being home alone while her family was occupied in the garden and the mother was briefly at the market to forcibly commit sexual intercourse against her. Neighbors intervened upon hearing the child’s cries, leading to the man’s arrest by local police in Wudabi Payam and subsequent transfer to the Morobo town police station on 15 April 2025. The victim was immediately taken to a health facility in Morobo Town for medical treatment and care on 15 April 2025. The investigation into the incident was conducted thoroughly, and the suspect remains in police custody pending trial before a competent county court. 

Comments: Legally, this act constitutes the heinous crime of rape against a minor, violating South Sudan’s Penal Code which criminalizes sexual offenses against children and mandates strict prosecution and protection measures. The case underscores the need for continued monitoring, victim support, and effective judicial follow-up to ensure accountability and deterrence of such egregious violations.

Location of Incident: Kor Kaya, Kendila Boma, Panyume Payam, Morobo County
Description:
•	Rape of a 9-year-old girl by a 45-year-old church leader in Kor Kaya, Kendila Boma, Panyume Payam, Morobo County 
On 04 September 2025, HRD YFO, received information from two reliable sources including a police officer and a humanitarian worker regarding the rape of a 9-year-old girl (details on file) by a 45-year-old church leader (details on file) in Kor Kaya, Kendila Boma, Panyume Payam, Morobo County on 23 August 2025. 

Sources reported that in the afternoon of 23 August 2025, a 45-year-old male church leader from the Keliko community encountered a 9-year-old girl, also from the Keliko tribe, along the road leading to an internally displaced persons (IDP) camp following Sunday service. According to the sources, the man offered to give the child a lift on his bicycle to the camp. The girl accepted; however, instead of proceeding directly to the IDP camp, the man diverted and stopped in a nearby bush area. It is reported that he forcibly took the child into the bushes and raped her. After the assault, he allegedly abandoned the victim, leaving her in pain and distress. The victim managed to return and reported the incident to her parents. In the aftermath, the alleged perpetrator attempted to flee the area. The victim received medical attention at a medical facility at the IDP camp. Community members, however, identified and apprehended him the following day, on 24 August 2025. He was subsequently handed over and transferred to the police station in Morobo Town, Morobo County, for further legal action.

Comments: Legally, this act constitutes the heinous crime of rape against a minor, violating South Sudan’s Penal Code which criminalizes sexual offenses against children and mandates strict prosecution and protection measures. The case underscores the need for continued monitoring, victim support, and effective judicial follow-up to ensure accountability and deterrence of such egregious violations.

Location of Incident: Ajak-Angou village of Malou-pech Payam under Cueibet County
Description:
A 12-year-old girl raped by a man in Ajak-Angou village of Malou-pech Payam under Cueibet County 

On 5 September 2025, HRD follow up on information regarding the alleged rape of a 12-year-old girl in Malou-pech Payam under Cueibet County. HRD was able to confirm with local authorities in Malou-pech Payam that, on 31 August 2025 at around 13.45 hours, the girl (name on file) from the Akoony clan of the Dinka Gok community was walking back to her village of Ajak-Angou in Malou-pech Payam from a local cattle camp with a group of girls. As she parted ways with the other girls in direction of her village, a man (name on file) followed her and forced her into the bush outside the village where he raped her. The man was arrested around 16.00 hours on the same day after the Police was alerted of the events and was placed in custody at the Malou-pech Payam Police Post. At 19.00 hours, as he was being transferred to Cueibet County Prison, the suspect managed to escape and has not since been apprehended. According to sources, the Police officers responsible for the suspect’s transfer were arrested for negligence.

Comments: HRD will continue to follow up on the case and evaluate whether the girl has been referred to appropriate services for care.

Location of Incident: Dinka Tribe in Majok-Yithiou a border town with Sudan and Aweil East County in Northern Bahr el-Ghazal State
Description:
Two Darfurian nationals raped 45-YO female civilian in Majok-Yithiou town, Aweil East County (Northern Bahr el-Ghazal).
On 11 September, Major, Agany Akol, Director of Joint police forces reported that on 9 September, two Darfurian nationals from Sudan raped 45-old female civilian from Dinka Tribe in Majok-Yithiou a border town with Sudan and Aweil East County in Northern Bahr el-Ghazal State. According to the source, the suspects Darfurian traders intercepted the victim, while they were travelling on a motorcycle around 10:00pm from Madhol to Majok-Yithiou town; thereafter abducted the victim and transferred her to an unknown location and raped her near Majok-Yithiou town. Reportedly, the two suspects were arrested by the police in the following day. Currently, culprits were under joint police-Militarily detention at Majok-Yithiou for further investigation. The survivor received medical treatment at Majok-Primary Heath Care Unit, whereupon the medical examination confirmed that the survivor was raped. The Director of the Jointed police force at Majok town informed that, one perpetrator confessed the commission of raped, whereas the other suspect denied the charge and intend to convince the family of the victim to accept compensation. Comment: HRD will follow up on the case for accountability of the perpetrator.

Location of Incident: Ayod, Ayod County of Jonglei State
Description:
Case of SGBV - Allegations of sexual assault of a girl by an adult male civilian in Ayod, Jonglei State

On 11 September HRD received information from credible sources alleging that a 15-year-old girl was sexually assaulted by a 50-year-old adult male civilian on 09 September in Ayod, Ayod County of Jonglei State. According to the sources, the victim girl lived in the same compound with the alleged perpetrator who sexually assaulted her at night inside the compound. 
It was reported that Ayod County authorities received a complaint and are investigating the alleged crime. 

Comment: HRD could not obtain information whether the victim received appropriate medical treatment given the absence of medical facilities in the County. HRD will continue to monitor, and advocate for accountability and  support to the victim.

Location of Incident: Udhum town, Aweil West County (Northern Bahr el-Ghazal).
Description:
42 YO man alleged raped 16 years old girl in Udhum town, Aweil West County (Northern Bahr el-Ghazal).
On 12 September, HRD, contacted Captain, Atak Atak, Director of the police station in Udhum Payam of Aweil West County (approx. 20km from the Aweil FO) reported that on 5 September, a 42 YO man alleged raped 16 years old girl in Udhum town, Aweil West County (Northern Bahr el-Ghazal). The incident occurred at the survivor home while her mother was away at the marketing day. Police officer did not arrested perpetrator while the culprit still in hiding. The uncle of the survivor, who is also an SSPDF soldier informed HRD that police at Udhum had failed to arrest the suspect and properly investigate the case, even refusing to issue a Form 8; this is a form used by the police for medical examinations during rape case. Hence, a survivor was not admitted to the hospital in Aweil town for treatment.
Comment:  HRD will follow up on the case for accountability of the perpetrator

Location of Incident: in Nyancok village of Matangai Payam, Rumbek Centre County
Description:
A 6-year-old boy was raped by his stepfather in Nyancot village of Rumbek Centre County

On 8 September 2025, HRD received information from one secondary source (Police authorities) to the effect that, on 24 August 2025, a 6-year-old boy (name on file) was raped by his stepfather (name on file) in Nyancok village of Matangai Payam, Rumbek Centre County. According to the source, the boy, who was the result of his mother’s extra-marital affair, lived with his mother and her husband, all members of the Nyang clan of the Kuei section of the Dinka Agaar community. On 23 August 2025, the boy’s mother went to spend two days at her own mother’s house, leaving her son alone in their home with his stepfather. The man took advantage of being left alone with the boy and raped him during the night. According to the source, this was an act of revenge by the stepfather as he had learned that his wife, the boy’s mother, wanted to divorce him and marry another man. When the mother returned home, her son told her about what had happened. She took him to the One Stop Centre in Rumbek town on 3 September 2025, where he received medical and psychosocial care. The One Stop Centre referred the mother to the Special Protection Unit where the Officer advised the mother to open a case. The man has since fled his village and is being searched for by the Police.   

Comments: HRD will continue to follow up on the case and the remedies put in place for the boy.

Location of Incident: Goja, Otogo Payam, Yei River County
Description:
•	Rape of an 18-year-old woman by an unidentified gang member in Goja, Otogo Payam, Yei River County 
On 11 September 2025, HRD YFO received and documented information from two reliable sources including a medical officer and counselor regarding the rape of an 18-year-old civilian woman resident at Goja, of the Kakwa tribe (details on file) by an unidentified gang member in Goja, Otogo Payam, Yei River County on 30 August 2025.  
According to the sources, the survivor was returning from her farm at about 11:00AM when she got intercepted by the man who was armed with a gun. From the story recounted by the sources, the armed man approached the lady in an isolated area, claiming to be new in the neighborhood and pretended to ask the lady for directions. While the lady was trying to help, he pounced on her and raped her before fleeing the scene, leaving the victim at the spot. The rape was not reported to the police as the victim felt reluctant to report a case about someone she cannot identify. However, she reported the case at a medical facility in Yei town on 1 September 2025 where the rape was confirmed and she was administered first aid treatment. 
Comments: The Penal Code Act (2008) criminalizes rape and other forms of sexual violence thus obligating the state to provide accessible justice and protective measures. The survivor’s reluctance to report to the police highlights the challenges faced in ensuring accountability and the proper administration of justice. HRD-YFO will continue to advocate with competent authorities to ensure accountability and justice for victims.

Location of Incident: in Luparate, Yei Town Payam, Yei River County
Description:
•	16-year-old civilian female from Congo DRC raped by an 18-year-old civilian male, in Luparate, Yei Town Payam, Yei River County.

On 10 September 2025, HRD-YFO received and documented information from two reliable secondary sources, including a medical officer and a community worker, regarding the rape of a 16-year-old civilian female from Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and resident of Hai-Leben in Yei Town (details on file) by a civilian male South Sudanese (details not provided) resident at Luparate. The incident happened in Luparate, Yei Town Payam, Yei River County on 04 August 2025. 

According to the sources the perpetrator who is suspected to be aged between 18 and 19 years of age reportedly invited the survivor to his friend’s residence in Luparate on 04 August 2025 where he raped her repeatedly and it resulted in pregnancy. The case was reported to the Yei Police Headquarters on 04 September 2025 by the survivor’s aunt, a lady said to be in her early 40s (details on file), and the survivor was referred to a medical facility in Yei Town for medical examination which confirmed the pregnancy. The perpetrator was arrested and detained at the Yei Police Headquarters on same day of report. 

Comments: This gruesome act of raping and impregnating a minor constitutes serious violation of the survivor’s bodily integrity and requires serious attention by authorities. HRD-YFO will follow up with police on the case for accountability purposes and proper administration of justice.

Location of Incident: in Bisellia Payam, Wau County
Description:
Alleged Rape of a 13-Year-Old Girl by Armed Cattle Keeper in Bisellia Payam, Wau County
On 10 September 2025, HRD interviewed a 13-year-old girl, a member of the Nuer community, who recounted that an armed cattle keeper from the Dinka community raped her. The perpetrator was reportedly part of a group that had established a cattle camp in Bisellia Payam, Wau County.
The survivor recounted that on 20 August 2025, around 2:00 pm, she was returning home after visiting her elder sister, whose house is located near the cattle camp. On her way back, the survivor was stopped at gunpoint by the armed cattle keeper, who threatened her not to move. The suspect identified himself by name (name on the file), and the survivor introduced herself as well. He then forcibly dragged her into a grassy area, tore off her clothing, and raped her. During the assault, the survivor screamed, which alerted her sibling. However, when someone approached the scene, later identified as her 17-year-old brother, the perpetrator threatened him at gunpoint, warning him to stay away. Amidst the chaos, the survivor managed to escape while the suspect was focused on threatening her sibling.
HRD also interviewed the survivor’s brother, who explained that he was grazing goats in the area when he heard piercing screams coming from the bush. As he approached, he saw the suspect assaulting someone, but did not initially realize it was his sister. The perpetrator pointed a gun at him and threatened to kill him if he came closer. After the survivor escaped, her brother followed her and discovered that she had been raped. He escorted her home and later returned to tend to the goats. 
The survivor and her brother reported the incident to their family. However, due to the absence of their father, who was on a three-day journey, the case was only reported to the Special Protection Unit (SPU) on 3 September 2025. The SPU issued Form 8, facilitating the survivor’s referral to a One-Stop Centre for medical treatment and psychosocial support. Upon the father’s return, he formally filed the case at the SPU station.
The police at the SPU confirmed that the case was registered under Section 247 of the South Sudan Penal Code Act of 2008. The suspect was subsequently apprehended. The survivor’s father, acting as the complainant, expressed his deep concern about the presence of the armed cattle camp in the area. He highlighted that the camp, run by heavily armed cattle keepers, had created insecurity and fear among civilians. The Payam 
Administrator of Bisellia Payam corroborated these concerns, stating that the cattle belonged to high-ranking commanders in the SSPDF. He noted that incidents of harassment and threats by the cattle keepers were frequent, further exacerbating the community's insecurity.
Comment: This incident underscores the broader issues of insecurity and lack of civilian protection in areas where armed cattle camps are established. Such camps not only threaten the safety of women and children but also undermine the fundamental rights of civilians, including their right to live free from violence and harassment. Efforts to address these issues must include disarming and regulating armed cattle keepers, ensuring justice for victims, and prioritizing the safety and security of vulnerable communities.

Location of Incident: Wedwil Refugee Settlement Camp in Aweil West
Description:
A woman from Darfur (refugee) suffering domestic violence and life threat from her husband.
On 16, September, HRD interviewed Darfurian woman came to visited HRD office from Wedwil Refugee Settlement Camp in Aweil West County seeking for protection. The victim informed HRD that she is suffering domestic violence and life threats from her husband who is also a refugee and adapt to be drunkard usually. The source informed that during at night her husband became wild, and he is trying to kill her with knife, but she saving to ran away and slept with her neighbor house. This case was reported to the Refugees Settlement management including UNHCR focal point and IRC and others INGOs, but her husband went on hiding during the day and came back at night or some time he spent somedays outside the camp if he is aware that there are people looking for him. 
On 23, July, her husband tortured her with stick at night and threw her to the open latrine and he ran away, when the neighbor and police arrived, they did not find him to be arrested. She was taken to the hospital in Aweil West County for treatment, where she left three children at home suffering to get food for survival. 
On the 02 August, a woman went to the customary court at Wedwil camp and appeared before the court seeking divorce from her husband as a result of the latter in house violent behavior, life threat and failure to provide adequate foodstuffs. The husband denied these allegations and disagreed with her wife. The court was adjourned to take place on 3rd September, but her husband went on hiding again. The suspect reportedly went into hiding and still threatening to kill her wife and he have not yet been apprehended.
 Comment: HRD has learnt that a woman with three children is seeking protection mechanisms, meanwhile there is omission from government authorities. In accordance with Article 2 of the UN Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment, UN Doc. CAT/C/GC/2, Para 18. Where there are reasonable grounds to believe that torture or ill-treatment are being committed there is a duty to “exercise due diligence to prevent, investigate, prosecute and punish such non-State officials or private actors”. HRD, will inform the concern authorities to investigate this case for accountability.

Location of Incident: Yambio Town, Yambio
Description:
•	HRD monitored the GBV One-Stop Centre in Yambio Town, Yambio County;

On 19 September, HRD visited the gender-based violence (GBV) One-Stop Centre located at the State Hospital in Yambio and met with a social worker who reported that between 4 and 19 September, 11 cases of GBV were received and treated. Of these, four cases involved rape of female minors aged between 14 and 16 years, with perpetrators being adult males aged between 18 and 26 years.

The remaining six cases involved domestic violence, including physical assault resulting in bodily injuries to the survivors. The survivors in these cases were adult females from the Azande community, while the perpetrators were adult males from the Azande and Dinka communities.

The first rape case reportedly took place in Tiimbiro Boma, Yambio town, on an unspecified date in August 2025. The survivor, a 15-year-old female from the Azande community, initially did not report the assault. Reportedly, on 8 September, the survivor’s parents discovered she was pregnant. According to the social worker, the perpetrator, a 19-year-old male civilian also from the Azande community, forcibly entered the victim’s room at night, tied her mouth, and raped her. Reportedly, he was subsequently arrested and remanded to prison.

The second case reportedly occurred on 7 September in the Kisanga residential area of Yambio town. Reportedly, the survivor, a 17-year-old female from the Azande community, was assaulted by a 30-year-old male from the Dinka community. Reportedly, the survivor received medical and psychosocial support; however, her parents later chose to withdraw the case from court and resolve it privately at home.

The third case involved a 14-year-old female minor from the Azande community and a 20-year-old male perpetrator in the Akorogbodi-1 (AK-1) residential area of Yambio. Reportedly, the survivor was accosted and dragged to the perpetrator’s room while returning from fetching water, where she was raped. The survivor received medical assistance, and the police arrested and remanded the perpetrator to prison.

The fourth rape case occurred in the Gangara Amelia residential area, Yambio town. Reportedly, the 14-year-old victim was returning from school when the perpetrator stopped her and demanded sex. Reportedly, when she resisted, his friends forced her into his room where she was assaulted. Reportedly, the survivor’s parents decided not to pursue legal action.
